label: nonarg

sentence: -- Just a clarification regarding the first contribution: WE from the current task is not used to generate a saliency map for the next task; it is instead used to instruct the learner of the next task about which input areas are more important than others via the attention mechanism.
label: dispute

sentence: This becomes a part of the future learning procedure, not just a post hoc visualisation method as in the original WE .
label: dispute

sentence: As such, the first contribution is not solely about generating new visualisations; it is more about using the learned saliency maps from the past to attend in future learners.
label: dispute

sentence: We therefore believe that the potential of this first contribution as a conceptual framework via which a learner can understand, attend, and then enhance its attention for future tasks, is not small.
label: nonarg

sentence: -- Importantly, we are the first to combine interpretability with continual learning and show that interpretability can help continual learning. It is a significant step to bring these two communities together.

sentence: In the following, we address each of the reviewers comments:
label: nonarg

sentence: > Table 4 should include the result of training a supervised network on top of random conv1/2 and Scattering network features […] Scattering is a perfectly fine approach for initial features.
label: nonarg

sentence: Our aim is to investigate the “power” (or lack thereof) of current self-supervision techniques when applied to standard deep network models.
label: concur

sentence: This is of interest because self-supervision is a hot topic of research.
label: concur

sentence: Finding whether e.g. the Scattering Transform can replace the first few layers of a network is interesting, for example to know if handcrafted features can also do as well as (self) supervision for the first few layers, but not susbtitutive of our core investigation (furthermore, we also look ad deeper layers, where these features are unlikely to be competitive).
label: dispute

sentence: Still, such an experiment can help put our findings in context.
label: concur

sentence: This is why we do include them in Table 2 of the paper, where we show that scattering is not quite as good as even single-image self-supervision.
label: concur

sentence: We do think that the suggestion of finetuning/retraining the rest of the model is also interesting after replacing the first few layers is also interesting.
label: concur

sentence: Still, we think that this can complement but not replace linear probing as the latter is a more direct way of finding what the probed layers can do.
label: dispute

sentence: For instance, it is likely possible to learn a good network even by replacing the first layer with the identity function — it is just a slightly less deep model.
label: dispute

sentence: For these two reasons, we are running the requested experiments and we hope to be able to update Table 4 in the following days.
label: dispute

sentence: > Can the authors clarify how the neural style transfer experiment is performed?
label: nonarg

sentence: Indeed, the method by Gatys et al. uses deeper layers as well, which we also use — straight from the self-supervised method, without fine-tuning or anything else.
label: concur

sentence: We will update the paper with these details.
label: concur

sentence: > While I appreciate the computational burden of testing more images, it does feel that Image A and B are quite cherry-picked in being very visually diverse. [...]  It might be interesting to try to generate synthetic images (or modify real ones) that are good for this purpose and observe their properties.
label: nonarg

sentence: Thank you, finding the best single training image, or finding useful synthetic images, are both very interesting ideas. While we are happy to consider doing so as a next step, it is next to impossible to do so in time for the rebuttal (we do not have access to thousands of GPUs).
label: dispute

sentence: Nevertheless, we would argue that the paper stands on by making some interesting observation on the ability of self-supervision to extract useful information from more than one (or few) images, and by investigating the role of data augmentation in this process.
label: dispute

sentence: We hope that the reviewer will agree that the community will be interested in hearing about these findings.
label: concur

sentence: > I disagree with the claim of practicality in the introduction (page 2, top). While training on one image does reduce the burden of number of images, the computational burden remains the same.
label: nonarg

sentence: Our intention wasn’t to say that we can save compute time, but data collection effort (which is also a practical issue in some applications).
label: dispute

sentence: Nevertheless, we agree that our findings have mostly a theoretical value, so we have adjusted the wording to reflect that.
label: concur

sentence: > And as mentioned above, it doesn’t seem likely that *any* image would work for this method.
label: nonarg

sentence: It is true that we did not quite prove that, so we have reworded the text to tone down this claim.
label: concur

sentence: To be a bit more specific, obviously a blank image would not work, and textureless images would probably not work well either.
label: concur

sentence: However, we did use in the paper the first two images we manually selected from Google Image Search (while we did select images with some texture, they have not been otherwise been optimized for good performance in our evaluation)
label: concur

sentence: Thus, we think that it is extremely likely that many other images would work just as well.
label: concur

sentence: > Finally, more images are needed to learn the deeper layers for the downstream task anyway.
label: nonarg

sentence: True, but even for deeper layers a single image achieves two thirds of the performance that self-supervision can squeeze out of a million images, which we think is interesting.
label: dispute

sentence: Thank you for your time and effort of reviewing our paper. Please see our response below.
label: nonarg

sentence: \kappa is an assistant notation to remove the ambiguity of the two \gammas in G_{\gamma}^{q_{\gamma} (y)}. \kappa stands for the parameter/variable of which the gradient information is needed.
label: concur

sentence: For example,
label: concur

sentence: (i) g_{\kappa}^{q_{\gamma}(y)} = frac{-1}{q_{\gamma}(y)} \nabla_{\kappa} Q_{\gamma}(y)}, where \kappa is \gamma, as in Theorem 1;
label: concur

sentence: (ii) g_{\kappa}^{q_{\gamma}(y|\lambda)} = frac{-1}{q_{\gamma}(y|\lambda)} \nabla_{\kappa} Q_{\gamma}(y |\lambda), where \kappa could be \gamma or \lambda.
label: concur

sentence: Eqs. (7) and (8) are the foundations GO is built on, but they are not our GO.
label: concur

sentence: GO is defined in Eq. (9) of Theorem 1.
label: concur

sentence: For Eq. (9), yes, y_{-v} is selected from one sample y in the experiments.
label: concur

sentence: But GO is not the local expectation gradient (Titsias & Lazaro-Gredilla, 2015), because GO uses different information (the derivative of the CDF and the difference of the expected function).
label: concur

sentence: As pointed out in the last paragraph of Sec. 3, when y_v has finite support and the computational cost is acceptable, one could use the local idea from Titsias & Lazaro-Gredilla(2015) for lower variance, namely analytically evaluate a part of expectations in Eq. (9).
label: concur

sentence: For a detailed example, please refer to Appendix I.
label: concur

sentence: The main difference between the local expectation gradient and the proposed GO is that the latter is applicable to where the former might not be applicable, such as where y_v has infinite support or the computational cost for the local expectation is prohibitive.
label: concur

sentence: Please note our GO is defined in Eq. (9).
label: concur

sentence: As pointed out in the last paragraph of Sec. 3, calculating Dy[f(y)] (requiring V+1 f evaluations) could be computationally expensive.
label: concur

sentence: We also stated there, “for f(y) often used in practice special properties hold that can be exploited for efﬁcient parallel computing”.
label: concur

sentence: We took the VAE experiment in Sec 7.2 as an example and gave in Appendix I its detailed analysis/implementation, in which you might be interested.
label: concur

sentence: More specifically, the two bullets after Table 4, should be able to address your question on fast speed.
label: concur

sentence: Also, as noted in the penultimate paragraph of Sec. 7.2, less parameters (without neural-network-parameterized control variant) could be another reason for GO’s efficiency.
label: concur

sentence: As for computation complexity, since different random variables (RVs) have different variable-nabla (as shown in Table 3 in Appendix), GO has different computation complexity for different RVs.
label: concur

sentence: After choosing a specific RV, one should be able to obtain GO’s computation complexity straightforwardly.
label: concur

sentence: For quantitative evaluation, the running time for each experiment has been given in the corresponding Appendix.
label: concur

sentence: Please check there if interested.
label: nonarg

sentence: Thank you for pointing out the concern on multi-sample-based REINFORCE.
label: concur

sentence: We have added another curve labeled REINFORCE2 to the one-dimensional NB experiments (see Fig. 8 for complete results), where the number 2 means using 2 samples to estimate the REINFORCE gradient.
label: concur

sentence: In this case, REINFORCE2 uses 2 samples and 2 f evaluations in each iteration, whereas GO uses 1 sample and 2 f evaluations.
label: concur

sentence: As expected, REINFORCE2 still exhibits higher variance than GO even in this simple one-dimensional setting.
label: concur

sentence: Multi-sample-based REINFORCE for other experiments is believed unnecessary, because (i) the variance of REINFORCE is well-known to increase with dimensionality; (ii) after all, if multi-sample-based REINFORCE works well in practice, why we need variance-reduction techniques?
label: nonarg

sentence: Please refer to Sec. 7.2 and Appendix I, the author released code from Grathwohl(2017) (github.com/duvenaud/relax) were run to obtain the results of REBAR and RELAX.
label: nonarg

sentence: We adopted the same hyperparameter settings therein for our GO.
label: concur

sentence: So, we do not think the hyperparameter settings favor our GO in the reported experiments.
label: concur

sentence: Please refer to the first paragraph of Sec. 7.2, “Since the statistical back-propagation in Theorem 3 cannot handle discrete internal variables, we focus on the single-latent-layer settings (1 layer of 200 Bernoulli random variables).”
label: concur

sentence: If you are interested, as stated in the last paragraph of Sec 7.2, we presented in Appendix B.4 a procedure to assist our methods in handling discrete internal RVs.
label: concur

sentence: We believe that procedure might be useful for the inference of models with discrete internal RVs (like the multi-layer discrete VAE).
label: concur

sentence: Please refer to the last paragraph of Appendix I, where we explained this misunderstanding in detail.
label: concur

sentence: In short, GO does not suffer more from overfitting; one reason is GO can provide higher validation ELBO.
label: concur

sentence: Actually, we believe it is GO’s efficiency that causes this misunderstanding.
label: concur

sentence: We hope your concerns have been addressed. If not, further discussion would be welcomed.
label: nonarg

sentence: Dear Reviewer 1, thank you for taking time to read and review our paper and for your useful comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: Hopefully the new results in our response will better aid discussion. Your specific points are addressed below.
label: nonarg

sentence: > “...the additions proposed are small modifications to existing algorithms
label: nonarg

sentence: We concede that the modifications to the existing models is a minor contribution.
label: concur

sentence: We would like to highlight that despite being a simple modification, producing an implementation that trains in a reasonable about ot time is non-trivial - this is confirmed by community comments requesting for implementation details.
label: dispute

sentence: We plan to make our code public to aid research in the area.
label: concur

sentence: To generalise the model, following the recommendations in one of the comments, we have investigated applying the Transformer-style dot product attention that was presented in GaAN (Zhang at al. 2018 https://arxiv.org/abs/1803.07294).
label: concur

sentence: This generalises the notion of RGAT, and we believe that this increase the contributions in terms of model modification that our paper offers.
label: concur

sentence: > “...and there are other methods of attention on graphs which have been discussed in the paper but not directly compared to (e.g. this method builds heavily on Velickovic et al 2017).”
label: nonarg

sentence: Unfortunately we cannot directly compare our approach to Velickovic et al. (2017) on relational graphs since their proposed model doesn’t support relationship types.
label: dispute

sentence: Hence, we only compare to Schlichtkrull et al. (2017) and the conventional baselines, whereas Velickovic et al (2017) reports results on the non-relational graphs Cora, Citeseer, Pubmed and PPI.
label: nonarg

sentence: In the case of the RDF tasks, our model hyperparameter search space does include a model very similar to vanilla GAT.
label: nonarg

sentence: In the case where we only have both one basis kernel for each of the convolution and the attention, i.e. where B_V and B_v in equation (8) are set to 1, then the difference between RGAT and GAT is only a set of learnable relative scale factors living inside the basis coefficients c_b and c_d.
label: nonarg

sentence: During our hyperparameter search, however, no favourable points for evaluation set performance were discovered with basis sizes lower than 10 (a basis size of 5 is permitted in the search).
label: nonarg

sentence: This leads us to conclude that vanilla GAT would not perform well on the RDF tasks.
label: nonarg

sentence: As mentioned above, we have now also evaluated the dot-product style attention of the transformer and have included it in our results.
label: concur

sentence: As one of the public comments mentioned, a study comparing these types of attention models to the more recurrent based models like Gated Graph Neural Networks (Li et al. 2015) would be extremely worthwhile.
label: nonarg

sentence: We we feel that evaluation lies outside of the scope of this work, however, which is mainly concerned with evaluating how the introduction of an attention mechanism into RGCN modifies its behaviour.
label: nonarg

sentence: > “...the results achieved in the experiments are very small improvements compared to the baseline of RGCN
label: nonarg

sentence: We agree that any improvements compared to RGCN are marginal.
label: concur

sentence: In light of your third comment (below) regarding hyperparameters, the new RGCN baseline on Tox21 significantly closes the gap between the baseline and sum-attention RGAT.
label: nonarg

sentence: The new dot product attention results on Tox21 (Mean test AUCs: WIRGAT 0.838 +/- 0.007, ARGAT 0.837 +/- 0.007) are slightly improved compared those of the sum attention, however, due to the retrained RGCN baseline, the relative gap between the best performing RGAT and RGCN is now smaller than it was before.
label: nonarg

sentence: We also see value in reporting these negative results.
label: nonarg

sentence: It was expected that an attention mechanism like GAT should cope with the node-degree imbalances observed to be present in the MUTAG dataset [a statement along these lines was made in Schlichtkrull et al. (2017)].
label: nonarg

sentence: The most natural route to tackle this problem turns out to fail - a result which we believe is informative for the community who are trying to solve this problem.
label: nonarg

sentence: On the other hand, the newly evaluated dot-product attention does no worse (or better) than RGCN, indicating a more promising research direction to pursue.
label: nonarg

sentence: > “...often these small variations in results can be compensated with better baselines training
label: nonarg

sentence: We also suspected this was a possibility, and in the same of sum-style attention it turns out to be true.
label: concur

sentence: To determine whether this was the case, we performed the same hyperparameter optimisations to our implementation of RGCN.
label: concur

sentence: In the case of the RDF datasets AIFB and MUTAG, we observe no meaningful difference between our retrained RGCN benchmark and the original benchmark provided in Schlichtkrull et al. (2017).
label: nonarg

sentence: On the other hand, our retrained implementation on the graph classification task TOX21 raised the performance above that of the RGCN reported in Wu et al, 2017 ti match the performance of the sum-style attention mechanism RGAT performance.
label: nonarg

sentence: This new RGCN performance is not higher than the observed performance of the dot-style attention mechanism, however, although this is not significant as discussed above.
label: nonarg

sentence: We thank for the reviewer for their comments on our work, and we share our responses below.
label: nonarg

sentence: 1) We agree that we did not provide a clear definition of "task".
label: concur

sentence: In the present paper there are two tasks: classification into primary labels, and classification into secondary labels.
label: concur

sentence: We did not mean to imply that the classification of a specific class is a task on its own.
label: concur

sentence: We agree however that a clearer introduction of the terminology would be clearly helpful and we plan to add this to the final submission.
label: concur

sentence: 2) This comment is not entirely correct and we would like to apologies for any confusion in the paper.
label: dispute

sentence: Actually, the update of the generator depends on the improvement of the classifier for the *principal* labels on the *meta-training* data, i.e. the improvement in generalisation to unseen data.
label: dispute

sentence: Thus, the optimal auxiliary labels are not the ground-truth labels for the principal classes, since this would make both terms in the minimisation for $\theta_1$ (the second equation in 3.2) identical and not allow any leveraging of the meta-training data.
label: dispute

sentence: Also, we would argue that the KL-divergence, rather then introducing noise, allows us to avoid collapsing classes which we would claim are due to dying neurons (again, there is not loss/mechanism drawing the auxiliary labels to be the same as the primary ones).
label: dispute

sentence: These claims are supported by showing that providing random labels does not lead to any improved performance and by our experience that using hard labels does indeed improve performance.
label: concur

sentence: 3) Providing fair comparisons across a range of very different methods is not easy when other methods aim to solve a different problem.
label: dispute

sentence: Concerning the comparison with prototypical networks, we do agree that this is not a fair comparison and we would like to change the phrasing in the paper.
label: concur

sentence: The original reason for associating this to the prototypical network was that we employ their zero-shot setup: i.e. we use a VGG network to obtain prototypes on the meta-data and then use these prototypes to define an auxiliary task on the training-data.
label: concur

sentence: 4) We do agree that requiring the class hierarchy is a current limitation of the work.
label: concur

sentence: While it is still general enough for solving classification tasks (we merely have to choose a fixed number of sub-classes per task, e.g. 5 without having to provide anything else), we would want to look at more general auxiliary task in future.
label: concur

sentence: One option we are considering is employing an auxiliary regression task, where the generator network would provide vectors and the corresponding loss would be simple regression.
label: concur

sentence: However, since this is the first work to use a double gradient method for auxiliary task generation, we believe that presenting results with a comparison to human auxiliary labels, which itself also requires this hierarchy, is a good starting point.
label: concur

sentence: 5) We would very much like to test our approach on more complex datasets with more varied classes, and this will be part of future work.
label: concur

sentence: However, we would like to repeat that our approach can work with an arbitrary hierarchy (e.g. assigning the same number of sub-classes to every class).
label: dispute

sentence: The reason why we only used 100 classes in our experiments is for allowing the comparison with human-defined classes, but in principle we could use any number of sub-classes per primary class.
label: dispute

sentence: In the CIFAR10 dataset in which a hierarchy is not defined, we show that using 6 different hierarchies all lead to a better generalisation.
label: dispute

sentence: We are afraid that there seems to be some confusion regarding our paper.
label: nonarg

sentence: We apologize if this is caused by the lack of clarity in the use of abbreviation “ES” (see general response).
label: concur

sentence: In the latest revision, “Evolutionary structure search” is abbreviated as “ESS” for clarity.
label: nonarg

sentence: We emphasize that in the paper, NO “evolutionary strategy” but rather PPO is used to train the policy (see Section 2.1 and 3.2).
label: nonarg

sentence: We hope the reviewer can take time to revisit the paper in the light of this inconsistency.
label: nonarg

sentence: Also, we now have 5 baselines from previous research and modern variants, which we believe further showcases our contributions.
label: nonarg

sentence: Q1: The experiments do not include any strong baseline
label: nonarg

sentence: We added more baselines to further strengthen the significance of our work with respect to the previous approaches.
label: concur

sentence: The baselines now include (a)“ESS-Sims” (Sims, 1994), (Cheney, 2014), (Taylor, 2017), (b) ESS-Sims-AF, (c) ESS-GM-UC, (d) ESS-BodyShare and (5) Random graph search.
label: nonarg

sentence: We refer to the details of each baseline in the general response.
label: nonarg

sentence: |      NGE         | ESS-Sims  | ESS-Sims-AF  | ESS-GM-UC | ESS-BodyShare |  RGS
label: nonarg

sentence: Walker   |
label: nonarg

sentence: The results show that NGE is significantly better than previous approaches and baselines.
label: nonarg

sentence: We did an ablation study by sequentially adding each sub-module of NGE separately.
label: nonarg

sentence: The table shows that submodules are effective and increase the performance of graph search.
label: nonarg

sentence: Q2: a) Optimizing both the controller and the hardware has been previously studied in the literature.
label: nonarg

sentence: Is it worth using a neural graph?
label: nonarg

sentence: b) All algorithms should optimize both G and theta for a fair comparison.
label: nonarg

sentence: By “optimizing both G and theta”, we meant to indicate that the learned controllers can be transferred to the next generation even if the topologies are changed (instead of throwing away old controllers).
label: dispute

sentence: We note that only NGE among all the baselines has the ability to do that.
label: dispute

sentence: Graph neural network formulation is KEY here, enabling it to perform this efficient policy transfer.
label: dispute

sentence: To the best of our knowledge, the traditional methods require re-optimizing theta from scratch for each different topology, which is computationally demanding and breaks the joint-optimization.
label: dispute

sentence: NGE approximately doubles the performance of previous approach (Sims, 1994) as shown in Q1.
label: dispute

sentence: Please refer to Section 3.1 and Section 3.4 for more details.
label: nonarg

sentence: Q3: You should use an existing ES implementation (e.g., from some well-known package) instead of a naive implementation, and as additional baseline also CMA-ES.
label: nonarg

sentence: Again, we apologize for the confusing use of “ES” abbreviation.
label: concur

sentence: Evolutionary strategy is not used in the paper.
label: dispute

sentence: We invite the reviewer to re-read our paper, since it seems to have led to a major misunderstanding.
label: nonarg

sentence: CMA-ES updates and utilize the covariance matrix of sampling distribution, which is not directly applicable to discrete structure optimization.
label: dispute

sentence: We believe it will be a valuable future research direction.
label: concur

sentence: Q4: Providing the same computational budget seem rather arbitrary and depends on implementation.
label: nonarg

sentence: We are unsure what the reviewer is indicating, and would appreciate the additional clarification.
label: nonarg

sentence: In terms of the computational budget for each experiment, we compared different algorithms under different computational budget metrics, more specifically,  “wall-clock time”, “number of updates”, and the “final converged performance”.
label: concur

sentence: NGE performs best among all algorithms.
label: concur

sentence: We emphasize the fact that wall-clock time is a more common and realistic metric for comparing the structure search in practice.
label: concur

sentence: We agree that computational budget depends on implementation, and the curves in the paper are plotted based on the number of iterations/parameter update, which is independent of the implementation.
label: concur

sentence: Q5: The writing of the paper
label: nonarg

sentence: We sincerely thank the reviewer for the suggestions.
label: nonarg

sentence: We updated the changes in the latest version accordingly.
label: concur

sentence: We would like to thank the reviewer for the time and useful feedback.
label: nonarg

sentence: Our response is given below.
label: nonarg

sentence: - Interpretation of self-modulation model performs worse in the combination of spectral normalization and the SNDC architecture.
label: concur

sentence: Overall, self-modulation appears to yield the most consistent improvement for the deeper ResNet architecture, than the shallower, more poorly performing, SNDC architecture.
label: concur

sentence: Self-modulation doesn’t help in the SNDC/Spectral Norm setting on the Bedroom data, where the SNDC architecture appears to perform very poorly compared to ResNet.
label: concur

sentence: For the other three datasets, self-modulation helps in this setting though.
label: concur

sentence: - The ablation study shows that the impact is highest when modulation is applied to the last layer (if only one layer is modulated).
label: nonarg

sentence: It seems modulation on layer 4 comes in as a close second.
label: nonarg

sentence: I am curious about why that might be.
label: nonarg

sentence: Figure 4 in the Appendix contains the equivalent of Figure 2(c) for all datasets.
label: concur

sentence: Considering all datasets: (1) Adding self-modulation to all layers performs best.
label: concur

sentence: (2) In terms of median performance, adding it to the layer farthest from the input is the most effective.
label: concur

sentence: We believe that the apparent significance of layer 4 in Figure 2(c) is statistical noise.
label: concur

sentence: - I would like to see some more interpretation on why this method works.
label: nonarg

sentence: We consider self-modulation as an architectural change in the line of changes such as residual connections or gating: simple, yet widely applicable and robust.
label: concur

sentence: As a first step, we provide a careful empirical evaluation of its benefits.
label: concur

sentence: While we have provided some diagnostics statistics, understanding deeply why this method helps will fuel interesting future research.
label: concur

sentence: Similar to residual connections, gating, dropout, and many other recent advances, more fundamental understanding will happen asynchronously and should not gate its adoption and usefulness for the community.
label: concur

sentence: - Did the authors inspect generated samples of the baseline and the proposed method? Is there a notable qualitative difference?
label: nonarg

sentence: A 10% change in FID is visually noticeable.
label: concur

sentence: However, we note that FID rewards both improvements in sample quality (precision) and mode coverage (recall), as discussed in Sec 5 of [1].
label: concur

sentence: While we can easily assess the former by visual inspection, the latter is extremely challenging.
label: concur

sentence: Therefore, an improvement in FID may not always be easily visible, but may indicate a better generative model of the data.
label: concur

sentence: [1] https://arxiv.org/abs/1806.00035
label: nonarg

sentence: - Overall, the idea is simple, the explanation is clear and experimentation is extensive. I would like to see more commentary on why this method might have long-term impact (or not).
label: nonarg

sentence: We view this contribution as a simple yet generic architecture modification which leads to performance improvements.
label: concur

sentence: Similarly to residual connections, we would like to see it used in GAN generator architectures, and more generally in decoder architectures in the long term.
label: concur

sentence: We thank the reviewer for their comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: Although our primary contributions are empirical, we also provided a detailed theoretical discussion in section 2, where we give a clear and simple account of why the two regimes arise.
label: dispute

sentence: Although previous authors have also discussed some of these results, there are differences between our conclusions, as we discussed in our responses to the other two reviewers.
label: dispute

sentence: We would also like to emphasize that we make a significant contribution to the debate regarding SGD and generalization.
label: dispute

sentence: While many papers have proposed that small batches may generalize better than large minibatches, it was recently pointed out by Shallue et al. that none of these experiments provide convincing evidence for this claim, because no experiment to date has compared small and large batch training under a constant step budget with a realistic learning rate decay schedule while independently tuning the learning rate at each batch size.
label: dispute

sentence: We are the first to run this experiment and conclusively establish that SGD noise does enhance generalization in popular models/datasets.
label: dispute

sentence: We believe this is an important contribution.
label: dispute

sentence: We also provide intriguing results as we vary the epoch budget, which demonstrate that the optimal learning rate which maximizes the test accuracy does not decrease as the epoch budget rises.
label: dispute

sentence: This supports the notion that SGD has an optimal “temperature” which biases it towards solutions that generalize well.
label: dispute

sentence: Additional experiments in the appendix G go further and study how the optimal learning rate schedule changes as we increase the epoch budget.
label: dispute

sentence: Thank you very much for the instructive and detailed review!
label: nonarg

sentence: For the first and second comments, we appreciate the detailed example you proposed.
label: nonarg

sentence: Specifically, we agree with the 1) and 2) of your analysis.
label: concur

sentence: For 3), although x^(1)_{t-2} is useful for predicting x^3_{t}, due to the causal chain and the presence of independent noise in the response function Eq. (1), x^(2)_{t-1} is even more useful for predicting x^(3)_{t}. When Eq. (2) is minimized w.r.t. both f_\theta and all \eta, with appropriate \lambda, it is likely that \eta_1 will go to infinity and \eta_2 will be finite, leading to the correct conclusion that X^(1)_{t-1} does not directly structurally cause x^(3)_t.
label: dispute

sentence: For example, in the new Appendix B.3, we show analytically and numerically that for a linear Gaussian system, the global minimum of the learnable noise risk lies on I(x^(1)_{t-2}; \tilde{x}^(1)_{t-2})=0, i.e. \eta_1->\infty, for a wide range of \lambda.
label: dispute

sentence: To study the general landscape and global minimum of the learnable noise risk, we first carefully inspect Theorem 2, and find that its original statement is not true in general.
label: dispute

sentence: We have replaced the original Theorem 2 with a detailed analysis of the loss landscape of the learnable noise risk.
label: dispute

sentence: Specifically, there are four properties that the minimum MSE (MMSE, the first term of the learnable noise risk after minimizing w.r.t. f_\theta) must obey, as demonstrated in the new Appendix B. In particular, we prove that the MMSE based only on the uncorrupted variables that directly structurally cause x^(i)_t is the minimum among all MMSE based on any set of uncorrupted variables.
label: dispute

sentence: These properties will likely lead to nonzero mutual information for the variables that directly structurally cause x^(i)_t, at the global minimum of the learnable noise risk, as we ramp down \lambda from infinity.
label: dispute

sentence: In a sense, the learnable noise risk behaves similarly as an L1 regularized risk.
label: dispute

sentence: Whereas L1 encourages sparsity of the parameters of the model, the mutual information term in the learnable noise risk encourages sparsity of the influence of the inputs, where the strength of sparsity inducing depends on \lambda.
label: dispute

sentence: As also pointed out in the “related works” in the revision, the learnable noise risk is invariant to model structure change (keeping the function mapping unchanged) and rescaling of inputs, while L1 or group L1 do not, making learnable noise risk suitable for causal discovery where the scale of data may span orders of magnitude and the model structure may vary.
label: dispute

sentence: For the third and fourth comment, thanks for pointing out and we have added the constraint-based methods in the related works section, and stressed that we are dealing with “causality in mean” in section 3.1.
label: concur

sentence: We thank the referee for their review and the summary of our results
label: nonarg

sentence: 1. We have included some more attacks on the most robust model (a transfer attack and a Gaussian random noise attack).
label: concur

sentence: (a) We have evaluated the adversarial resistance when training a Boltzmann machine with 256 fully connected latent variables directly on the 8x8 patches.
label: concur

sentence: The version with only 128 hidden units was not able to reduce the relative entropy to the values of the larger, stacked machine.
label: concur

sentence: We find that the model without stacking is not able to increase the adversarial resistance.
label: concur

sentence: It is possible that we are unable to complete the training due to the approximations involved.
label: concur

sentence: For a small machine (16 units) of full hidden connectivity we can observe the noise rejection behaviour, as shown in appendix D.
label: concur

sentence: (b) We have trained a machine with the same connectivity as the stacked machine directly on the 8x8 patches.
label: concur

sentence: This training gives similar results to the training in stages.
label: nonarg

sentence: (c) From the result in (b) we conclude that the particular manner of the pre-training does not matter.
label: nonarg

sentence: Therefore also the choice of first training set (98% coverage or full coverage) does not influence adversarial resistance.
label: nonarg

sentence: (d) There are a total of 28800 parameters in the Boltzmann machine.
label: concur

sentence: We will gladly provide files with the trained weights and also fully trained neural networks on request.
label: nonarg

sentence: 3. We currently do not have a full explanation for the large adversarial resistance, but noise resistance must play a part in it.
label: concur

sentence: The very strong rejection of Gaussian noise and the observations in Fig. 4 point in this direction.
label: concur

sentence: With all our due respect to Reviewer #3’s valuable time and effort in reviewing our manuscript, we must admit that we are a bit upset by this last late review, due to the apparent lack of understanding before placing comments, and several factual errors that make the current comments at least poorly grounded.
label: dispute

sentence: We understand that the idea of “model falsification as model comparison” might not be trivial to understand for people primarily from practical deep learning backgrounds.
label: concur

sentence: The idea is deeply rooted in a successful series of studies from image perceptual assessment research: a basic introduction can be found in (Wang & Simoncelli (2008)).
label: concur

sentence: We notice that Reviewer #2 also kindly points out another interdisciplinary foundation of MAD in software differential testing.
label: concur

sentence: We hope Reviewer #3 can carefully read the below explanation, and reconsider the rating to a more serious and appropriate one.
label: nonarg

sentence: One of the main advantages is that it can select a sample set from an arbitrarily large unlabeled images.
label: nonarg

sentence: However, to compare different classifiers, the proposed algorithm still needs humans to annotate the selected dataset, which is very expensive compared with traditional methods.
label: nonarg

sentence: Response:
label: nonarg

sentence: Our method is very efficient in terms of human annotation budget compared with traditional methods, which is one of the main claims we elaborated in our paper.
label: dispute

sentence: We are disappointed that this major important point was not well understood.
label: dispute

sentence: In fact, MAD provides the very first and efficient solution (in the context of image classification) to exploit a large-scale image set under the constraint of the very limited budget for human labeling.
label: dispute

sentence: We have noticed that the other two reviewers agree with us and appreciate this point.
label: dispute

sentence: For example, quote Reviewer #2: “Because of the efficacy of such "worst-case" comparison, the needed set size is very small and thus minimizes the human annotation workload”.
label: dispute

sentence: To evaluate the relative performance of two ImageNet classifiers, traditional evaluation methods compute accuracy on a fixed test set.
label: dispute

sentence: For ImageNet validation set, human annotations for 50,000 images need to be provided.
label: dispute

sentence: This number is large in terms of human labeling effort, but is extremely small compared to the set of all natural images (the natural image manifold).
label: dispute

sentence: As also mentioned by the reviewer, annotation for each image is a 1000-class classification task, which makes the labeling task more difficult compared to a binary classification problem.
label: dispute

sentence: In contrast, rather than comparing fixed test sets which are typically small, the proposed MAD adaptively samples a test set from an arbitrarily large corpus of unlabeled images so as to maximize the discrepancies between the classifiers, measured by the distance over WordNet hierarchy.
label: dispute

sentence: Human labeling is only required on the resulting small and model-dependent image sets, which contains only k=30 images (for each pair of classifiers) on the ImageNet experiment as reported in our paper.
label: dispute

sentence: Our experiments show that the MAD ranking stabilizes at around k>15 (see figure 5) and successfully tracks the recent progress in image classification .
label: dispute

sentence: For comparing 11 classifiers, the total labeled images needed are 1,650 (see page 6): it is obviously smaller than 50,000 and leaves much room to compare more classifiers (before it reaches 50, 000).
label: dispute

sentence: In conclusion, our method is apparently much more efficient in terms of human annotation budget compared with traditional methods.
label: dispute

sentence: In addition, despite the fact that the selected set by MAD is small (as a way of maximizing the efficiency of human labeling), it provides the strongest examples to let classifiers compete with one another.
label: dispute

sentence: Quote Reviewer #2: “The proposed MAD competition distinguishes classifiers by finding their respective counterexamples. It is therefore an "error spotting" mechanism”.
label: dispute

sentence: Their respective strengths, weaknesses as well as biases can be most easily revealed (see figures in the appendix), which sheds light on potential ways to improve the classifiers or combine them into a better one.
label: dispute

sentence: Those gains are way beyond the scope of collecting random image samples.
label: dispute

sentence: Q2: Since this paper select the top-k images in D, if k is large the annotating for S will be very tedious, however if k is relatively small the method seems very sensitive to selected examples, which will make the comparison not totally convincing.
label: nonarg

sentence: Response:
label: nonarg

sentence: We agree with the reviewer that k is a critical parameter in MAD.
label: concur

sentence: We want to however draw the reviewer’s attention to the ablation study and figure 5, if they were accidentally missed in the first reading.
label: concur

sentence: Based on them, we cannot concur with the statement “if k is relatively small the method seems very sensitive to selected examples”.
label: dispute

sentence: When we apply MAD to compare imageNet classifiers, we find that the MAD ranking stabilizes very quickly when around k>15.
label: concur

sentence: We would like to also emphasize that despite the small size of labeled images, MAD successfully tracks the steady progress in image classification, as verified by a reasonable Spearman rank-order correlation coefficient (SRCC) of 0.89 between the accuracy rank on ImageNet validation set and the MAD rank on our test set.
label: concur

sentence: As also pointed out by Review #2, the selected top-k images provide the strongest examples to let classifiers compete with one another.
label: concur

sentence: Through this process, their respective strengths, weaknesses as well as biases can be most easily revealed (see figures in the appendix).
label: concur

sentence: Q3: The authors invite five volunteer graduate students to annotate the selected example.
label: nonarg

sentence: However, for many categories, it’s nor easy for normal people to distinguish.
label: nonarg

sentence: So the experiments in this paper is also not convincing.
label: nonarg

sentence: Response:
label: nonarg

sentence: As veterans in performing subjective studies, we understand and agree with the reviewer that querying ground truth labels for a 200-class classification problem is difficult. That is exactly why we have carefully designed our subjective experiment.
label: concur

sentence: Given an image x, which is associated with two classifiers f_i and f_j , we pick two binary questions for human annotators: “Does x contain an f_i(x)?” and “Does x contain an f_j (x)?”.
label: concur

sentence: For each question, we follow  the original ImageNet instructions and include the definition of f_i(x) (or f_j(x))  with a link to a corresponding Wikipedia page.
label: concur

sentence: We also show several example images of f_i(x) (or f_j(x)) sampled from the ImageNet validation set.
label: concur

sentence: Moreover, if more than three of our five human annotators find difficulty in labeling x, it is discarded and replaced.
label: concur

sentence: When both answers to the two binary questions are false (corresponding to Case III), we cease to source the ground-truth label of x for reasons mentioned by the reviewer, and treat x as a strong counterexample for both f_i and f_j.
label: concur

sentence: Based on the above, we cannot concur with the judgement “the experiments in this paper is (are) also not convincing”.
label: dispute

sentence: We’re glad that you found the paper interesting and well-written. To address your comments and questions:
label: nonarg

sentence: 1. the NPN model seems a good alternative, will be good to have a discussion about why your model is better than NPN.

label: nonarg

sentence: The NPN model requires a pre-defined lexicon of action types (i.e., verbs), such as cut, bake, boil, etc.
label: dispute

sentence: For the recipes dataset, the action types and their causal effects were manually collected and defined.
label: dispute

sentence: Since the ProPara dataset does not have these annotations, we would have to manually identify action types to apply NPN to it.
label: dispute

sentence: Also, NPN treats the state change as a classification problem (of about 260 classes that are also manually defined).
label: dispute

sentence: In contrast, KG-MRC finds the state-describing span in the text directly, which we believe is a more generic approach.
label: dispute

sentence: 2. A more detailed illustration of the system / network is needed. Would have made it much easier to understand the paper.
label: nonarg

sentence: We agree that more detail would help readers to understand the model better.
label: concur

sentence: We’ve made some hopefully significant updates to Section 4 (model description and notation) to improve clarity, and we hope you’ll take the time to read the new manuscript.
label: concur

sentence: Two important additions are a high-level summary of the model, which we give at the beginning of Section 4, and a table (Table 2) that lists what each symbol represents along with its dimensions.

sentence: 3. What are the results when using the whole training set of Recipes ?
label: nonarg

sentence: We’ve completed an experiment on the full Recipes dataset and updated the paper to describe the result (this experiment did not finish in time for the initial submission).
label: concur

sentence: The model’s F1 score improves from 51.64 on the partial data to 54.27 on the full data, surpassing the previous state of the art by a more significant margin.

sentence: Thanks for the review.
label: nonarg

sentence: There are two significant inaccuracies:
label: nonarg

sentence: 1. GGT does not take the view of a low-rank *approximation*. This is a central point of the paper.
label: dispute

sentence: 2. Re: iterative methods: the preconditioner is a -1/2 power of the Gram matrix, not the inverse.
label: dispute

sentence: More details below:
label: nonarg

sentence: @Inverse square root: We are fully aware of the distinction.
label: concur

sentence: - Note that iterative solvers like conjugate gradient do not immediately apply here, as we are solving a linear system in M^{1/2}, not M.
label: concur

sentence: - Krylov subspace iterative solvers suffer from a condition number dependence, incurring a hard tradeoff between iteration complexity and \eps. [1]
label: concur

sentence: - We actually *did* try polynomial approximations to M^{-1/2} as an alternative to our proposed small-SVD step.
label: concur

sentence: We saw worse approximation (the condition number dependence kicks in) and worse GPU performance (parallel computation time scales with polynomial degree).
label: concur

sentence: @Full-matrix terminology: The use of “full-matrix” to distinguish from “diagonal-matrix” is standard, and taken directly from [2].
label: dispute

sentence: @Full-matrix vs. full-rank: Note that we do not consider the windowed Gram matrix to be an “approximation” of the “full” gram matrix.
label: dispute

sentence: The window is for the purpose of forgetting gradients from the distant past, motivated by (1) our theory, (2) the small-scale synthetic experiments, and (3) the extreme ubiquity of Adam and RMSprop, which do the same.
label: dispute

sentence: Note that we do no approximation on the windowed Gram matrix, the fact that it is low rank is a feature.
label: dispute

sentence: @Location of \mu definition: Is the reviewer’s suggestion simply to move this definition into the intro?
label: nonarg

sentence: @Comparison with second-order methods
label: nonarg

sentence: : Please refer to our response to Reviewer 1 for some additional comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: @Tweaks: We don’t believe that any of the tweaks should be so controversial.
label: dispute

sentence: - The \eps parameters are present in *every* adaptive optimizer, for stability.
label: dispute

sentence: The interpolation with SGD is just another take on this.
label: dispute

sentence: - The exponential smoothing of the first moment estimator is a subtler point.
label: dispute

sentence: As we point out in Appendix A.2, in the theory for Adam/AMSgrad [3,4], \beta_1 *degrades* the moment estimation, yet everyone uses momentum in practice.
label: dispute

sentence: Even if this is unconvincing, the performance gap upon removing this tweak is minor, and our empirical results hold without this tweak.
label: dispute

sentence: We are simply offering a heuristic that we have observed to help training unconditionally, just like momentum in Adam.
label: dispute

sentence: @Informal main theorem: By “informal” we truly mean that we are suppressing the smoothness constants (L, M) for readability and space constraints. We are simply adopting the widespread practice of deferring the non-asymptotic mathematical statement to the appendix.
label: concur

sentence: Thank you for your feedback and additional references! To address the comments:
label: nonarg

sentence: - As we explained in Thm.1, \eta_{\mathcal{H}} is a constant measuring how well the model family \mathcal{H} can fit the true models from both domains.
label: concur

sentence: Estimating this term requires *labelled* target samples, which is usually unavailable in domain adaptation.
label: concur

sentence: However, when we have access to a handful of labelled target data, we can certainly estimate this term and perform model selection (e.g., choosing neural network models \mathcal{H}) better, meaning that we can find better values for alphas, and so achieve even better adaptation performance.
label: concur

sentence: - Yes, there are many methods that conduct single-source to single-target adaption in the literature.
label: dispute

sentence: However, our main focus is *multi-source* to single-target adaptation.
label: dispute

sentence: This is why our comparisons focus on similar methods, that also use multiple sources at the same time.
label: dispute

sentence: They are generally more competitive than single-source methods.
label: dispute

sentence: Following Reviewer #1's suggestions, we added one additional state-of-the-art competitor, Moment Matching for Multi-Source Domain Adaptation (M3SDA) (Peng et al., 2019), to our experiments.
label: concur

sentence: Moreover, we also add the challenging Office-Home dataset as you suggested[D]; results can be found in the new Section 5.3.
label: concur

sentence: The results with the new competitor, and on both the earlier datasets and the new one, show that our method outperforms the competition, especially on the Office-Home dataset, in which we achieve state-of-the-art performance.

sentence: Except for the learning rate, all the hyper-parameters were chosen according to the values suggested by the authors of AdaGrad, and Adam.
label: concur

sentence: The learning rate was chosen as 1/K, with K=100 being the number of examples used to estimate the CDF.
label: concur

sentence: As our stated goal is to present an algorithm which can be blindly applied with some fixed set of hyper-parameters to any possible objective, one of the goals of the experiments is to show that in such a setting some methods will work, while others will fail.
label: concur

sentence: Thus, as a controlled experiment for this hypothesis, we first fixed the set of all hyper-parameters for all methods, and then proceeded to apply them to various problems.
label: concur

sentence: In this setting therefore, tuning the learning rate or any other hyper-parameter for that matter will compromise the validity of our results.
label: concur

sentence: Regarding table 3, we accept the reviewer’s suggestion, this is a good point. We particularly like the suggestion of writing NA or some such value, and we will use it to correct the paper.

sentence: Please see our detailed response to several recurring issues at https://openreview.net/forum?id=Hkx-ii05FQ&noteId=HygFbNmL6X.
label: nonarg

sentence: In that response we address the following issues:
label: nonarg

sentence: (1) We emphasize fundamental differences between Cakewalk and CE.
label: nonarg

sentence: These go beyond the differences the reviewer mentions.
label: nonarg

sentence: (2) How the sampling distribution should not be considered as a part of Cakewalk, and that it is mostly provided as an example, and a basis for the reported experiments.
label: nonarg

sentence: (3) The experiments include results two tasks.
label: nonarg

sentence: Nonetheless, it appears the paper doesn’t convey this clearly, and we suggest two possible ways how to update the paper in this regard.
label: nonarg

sentence: Next, we try to answer the specific issues the reviewer mentions.
label: nonarg

sentence: First, we address the suggestion of introducing Cakewalk as a generalization of CE.
label: nonarg

sentence: While we were writing the paper we in fact considered presenting Cakewalk as the reviewer suggests.
label: concur

sentence: We eventually decided against this approach as CE is a method for adapting an importance sampler, and its convergence guarantees only apply when it is treated as such.
label: concur

sentence: The convergence guarantees of REINFORCE on the other hand still apply under our surrogate objective framework.
label: concur

sentence: This property allows us to explore various surrogates, where one such construction allows us to interpret CE as a policy gradient method, and another makes the basis for Cakewalk.
label: concur

sentence: Second, we address the issue of using a sampling distribution that assumes independence between the different dimensions.
label: nonarg

sentence: As the author correctly states, such a distribution will not always be useful, and one can design a problem for which this distribution will lead to a poor local optimum.
label: concur

sentence: Note however that a global maximizer for the objective suggested by the reviewer can be easily found just by random sampling: sampling such a maximizer has the same probably as sampling an odd integer - half.
label: dispute

sentence: Nonetheless, for the clique problem such a distribution can be effective.
label: dispute

sentence: Intuitively, if some node i is part of a large clique, then sampling x_i=1 is likely to result in a good objective as there are many nodes that are connected to i, and the chance of not sampling any of them decreases with the clique size.
label: concur

sentence: In this way, over time the probability for sampling such nodes becomes higher, and the chance of sampling all of them together increases.
label: concur

sentence: A similar reasoning applies for the k-medoids problem.
label: concur

sentence: We note that these kind of factorized distributions have a long history of being useful in machine learning.
label: concur

sentence: In a similar context to the one studied in the paper, such distributions have been studied by Rubinstein in his paper which discusses CE as an algorithm for combinatorial optimization, and in the classical bandit papers Exp3 is applied independently to several dimensions to study game theoretic problems.
label: concur

sentence: In different contexts, such distributions have also been used as naive mean field approximations in variational inference.
label: concur

sentence: Next, we address the question regarding the gradient update types.
label: nonarg

sentence: One intuitive explanation for why an algorithm that maintains a ‘memory’ of previous gradient updates like AdaGrad or Adam is required
label: concur

sentence: is that they protect against sampling biases.
label: concur

sentence: Consider for example the case when the execution is at the start, and the sampling distribution still has maximum entropy.
label: concur

sentence: Due to the combinatorial nature of the solution space, the examples that have been sampled thus far create a distorted representation of the solution space.
label: concur

sentence: In this case we could get that some x_i=j will occur few times, while some other x_k will not receive the value j at all.
label: concur

sentence: Now if we apply vanilla gradient updates this can skew the sampling distribution in random directions.
label: concur

sentence: Gradient updates such as those of AdaGrad and Adam on the other hand will lessen the impact of such deviations as the importance of each case is inversely proportional to the number of previous observations.
label: concur

sentence: As such deviations will inevitably occur whenever we rely on polynomially sized samples to represent a combinatorial solution space, without such corrections a gradient based adaptive sampling algorithm will almost surely fail.
label: concur

sentence: Indeed, as can be seen in tables 1,2 and 4, SGA almost never leads to a locally optimal solution.
label: nonarg

sentence: Furthermore, this reasoning explains why AdaGrad is superior to Adam: AdaGrad corrects against sampling biases that entail all the examples that have been encountered, while Adam does this only within some exponentially moving time window.
label: concur

sentence: Indeed, this phenomenon is studied in detail in the AdaGrad paper (though without assuming a data distribution), and sparse data like ours (one can say our data points are N indicator vectors of length M) is the first motivating example in their paper.
label: concur

sentence: Thank you very much for your time, and your constructive comments, we are looking forward to further discussions!
label: nonarg

sentence: We answer your questions and concerns in the following.
label: nonarg

sentence: > "The advantage of INN is not crystal clear to me versus other generative methods such as GAN and VAE."
label: nonarg

sentence: It is indeed possible to adapt other network types to the task of predicting conditional posteriors.
label: concur

sentence: We are currently setting up experiments for detailed analysis of the respective advantages and disadvantages and will report about these results in a future paper.
label: concur

sentence: In the present paper, we focus on demonstrating that high-quality posteriors can actually be learned using bi-directional training as facilitated by INNs.
label: concur

sentence: Concerning the comments/questions:
label: nonarg

sentence: > "could the authors elaborate on the comparison against cGAN"
label: nonarg

sentence: cGAN generators are at an inherent disadvantage relative to INNs, because they never see ground-truth pairs (x,y) directly -- they are only informed about them indirectly via discriminator gradients.
label: concur

sentence: This it not a problem for simple relationships, e.g. between images x and attributes y, and cGANs work very well there.
label: concur

sentence: However, it makes learning of complicated forward processes much harder and may cause the resulting posteriors to be inaccurate.
label: concur

sentence: Moreover, INNs are forced to embed every training point x somewhere in the latent space, whereas cGAN generators may fail to allocate latent space for some x, because this is never explicitly penalized.
label: concur

sentence: This can lead to mode collapse and insufficient diversity.
label: concur

sentence: > "Can cGAN be used to estimate the density of X (posterior or not)?"
label: nonarg

sentence: cGANs can in principle do this by choosing a generator architecture with tractable Jacobian (using e.g. coupling layers or autoregressive flow), but we are not aware of published results about this possibility.
label: concur

sentence: > "For the bidirectional training, did the ratios of the losses (L_z, L_y, L_x) have to be changed, or the iterations of forward/backward trainings have to be changed (e.g., 1 forward, 1 backward vs. 2 forward, 1 backward)?"
label: nonarg

sentence: Yes, the weights of the losses are considered as hyperparameters, because the magnitude of MMD-based losses depends on the chosen kernel function.
label: concur

sentence: Hyperparameter optimization suggested an up-weighting of MMD-based losses by a factor of 5, to give them approximately equal impact as the supervised loss.
label: concur

sentence: For the iterations, we accumulated gradients over one forward and one inverse network execution before each parameter update.
label: concur

sentence: We also tried alternating parameter updates after each forward and backward pass, which resulted in equal accuracy, but was a bit slower.
label: concur

sentence: We did not experiment with other ratios than 1:1.
label: concur

sentence: > "Is this to effectively increase the intermediate network dimensions?"
label: nonarg

sentence: This is precisely the reason: It improves the representational power of the INN, as mentioned in Sec. 3.2 and discussed in our response to reviewer 1.
label: concur

sentence: At present, we find this is only necessary for the toy problem in Fig. 2.
label: concur

sentence: > "It seems that there needs some way to enforce them to be zero to ensure that the propagation happens only among the entries belonging to the variables of interests (x, y and z)."
label: nonarg

sentence: This is correct.
label: concur

sentence: We explicitly prevent information from being hidden in the padding dimensions in the following way:
label: concur

sentence: A squared loss ensures that the amplitudes are close to zero.
label: concur

sentence: In an additional inverse training pass, we overwrite the padding dimensions with noise of the same amplitude, and minimize their effect via a reconstruction loss.
label: concur

sentence: We will add this to the relevant paragraph in the paper.
label: concur

sentence: > "I am curious if this model could succeed on higher dimensional data"
label: nonarg

sentence: Works such as [1, 2, 3] (also cited in our paper) have shown that the coupling layer architecture in general works well with images.
label: concur

sentence: These works use maximum likelihood training, i.e. exploit the tractable Jacobians to maximize the likelihood of the data embedding in latent space.
label: concur

sentence: To scale-up our approach, we may need to replace MMD loss with maximum likelihood as well, and first experiments with this show promising results, see
label: concur

sentence: https://i.imgur.com/ft09Pk9.png .
label: concur
