sentence: >> Would it be possible to train the vq-wav2vec model jointly with BERT, i.e. as one model? [...] Similarly to the above question, would there be a way to incorporate the BERT principles directly into an end-to-end model, e.g. by randomly masking some of the continuous input speech?
label: nonarg

sentence: The focus of this paper is a quantization approach for audio.
label: concur

sentence: Replacing the two-step training process by an adaptation of BERT to continuous data (using a wav2vec/CPC-like objective function instead of the cross entropy) is an interesting direction for future work (and we amended the future work section accordingly).
label: concur

sentence: However, our current paper is a proof of concept that a pre-training scheme based on masked inputs (BERT) can improve over previous methods in the speech domain.
label: concur

sentence: >> What exactly does "mode collapse" refer to in this context?
label: nonarg

sentence: In several configurations (especially for one and two groups) considerably less codewords than theoretically possible are used.
label: concur

sentence: We loosely refer to mode collapse as the phenomenon when very few codewords per group are used (cf. Appendix A).
label: concur

sentence: We updated the paper to also refer to the appendix where we outline the number of codewords that the model uses.
label: concur

sentence: We observed that in the “few group regime” (G=1...4), only a few of the available centroids per group are used and refer to this phenomenon as mode collapse — for BERT training, this is actually favorable e.g. in the G=2, V=320 setting as it yields a codebook of acceptable size for NLP model training (13.5k/23k).
label: concur

sentence: Mode collapse could potentially be circumvented by strategies like embedding re-initialization used in classical k-means and this is an interesting avenue for future work.
label: concur

sentence: >> [...] BERT is required on top of the vq-wav2vec discrete symbols.
label: nonarg

sentence: Is it possible that the output acoustic model is simply better-matched to continuous rather than discrete input (direct vq-wav2vec gives discrete while BERT gives continuous)? Would it make sense to train the wav2vec acoustic model on top of the vqvae codebook entries (e) instead of directly on the symbols?
label: nonarg

sentence: We actually did what you suggest: when we train acoustic models on top of vq-wav2vec, we input the dense embedding vectors corresponding to the discrete codewords.
label: concur

sentence: On the other hand, we also trained an NLP sequence to sequence (Section 6.3) which takes the quantized audio codes as input and then generates the transcriptions.
label: concur

sentence: This gives reasonable accuracy and suggests that the discrete codes by themselves, and without the learned continuous representations, are useful.
label: concur

sentence: We clarified this in the updated version of the paper.
label: concur

sentence: We believe the reason the dense embeddings for the discrete codewords work less well
label: concur

sentence: is because they do not encode as much detailed context information as a representation built by wav2vec or BERT.
label: concur

sentence: The information in the codebook is ultimately less detailed than a context vector specific to the current input sequence.
label: concur

sentence: The main topic of the paper is how to evaluate models that use confidence thresholding.
label: dispute

sentence: The primary purpose is to compare *defenses*. However, to justify the attack strategy that we propose to use, we also compare *attacks*. Specifically, we provide an experiment demonstrating that our attack actually is stronger than the baseline.
label: dispute

sentence: However, it is not really necessary to provide multiple experiments demonstrating that MaxConfidence is more powerful because the superiority of MaxConfidence is theoretically guaranteed.
label: dispute

sentence: We are aware of the related work you mention.
label: concur

sentence: Please note that unfortunately the “Semantically Conditioned LSTM…” is not directly comparable because, as they state in their paper, “the generator is further conditioned on a control vector d, a 1-hot representation of the dialogue act (DA) type and its slot-value pairs”.
label: dispute

sentence: Our goal is to work with arbitrarily complex questions that map to correspondingly arbitrarily complex logical forms and not a very restricted set of logical forms that could be represented in a one-hot fashion.
label: dispute

sentence: Please do note that we ran 2 sets of human evaluations (Adequacy and Fluency), as is standard in Machine translation in order to deal with the evaluation bias problem you describe - we took this into account when conducting experiments and will make it more clear in a revised version.
label: concur

sentence: We also observe significant improvements in both human evaluations, suggesting that the improvement comes from our method and not from evaluation bias.
label: concur

sentence: Our dataset only contains a single logical form for each question and vice-versa, making it impossible to evaluate quantitative metrics (bleu, rouge, meteor) in the multi-reference setting you describe.
label: dispute

sentence: Please also note that metrics like bleu and rouge have been commonly used in a non multi-reference setting by significant work in the natural language processing community.
label: dispute

sentence: We thank the reviewer for their comments and will take them into account in a revised version.
label: concur

sentence: We thank the reviewer for their time and their clear understanding of the key aspects of the paper.
label: nonarg

sentence: We address the reviewer’s questions in the following:
label: nonarg

sentence: >  How much does the image matter for the single-image data set?
label: nonarg

sentence: The reviewer raises an important point about the tested single images.
label: concur

sentence: Less crowded images could lead to many patches having no gradients (e.g. showing only the sky), leading to a failure of at least RotNet, if not also BiGAN on many samples of the augmented dataset.
label: concur

sentence: Our image choices were thus motivated by striving for simplicity and not further adding a pipeline that would, for example, extract only patches with sufficiently large image gradients.
label: concur

sentence: We are training DeepCluster now on a significantly less busy image and will report results in the coming days.
label: concur

sentence: >  How general is the proposed approach?
label: nonarg

sentence: We believe that this method will work well for pretext tasks that rely on learning via detecting and learning invariances, such as Exemplar [1], Colorization [2], and Noise-as-targets [3].
label: concur

sentence: Methods such as Context [4] and Jigsaw [5] could potentially work less well as they would potentially easily find a way to cheat given the limited amount of original data of one image.
label: concur

sentence: However, as the authors note in the paper cited by the reviewer, the accuracy of a pretext task does not translate to downstream task performances, so even a method that is simple on one image’s patches does not necessarily fail.
label: concur

sentence: This is an interesting avenue for research and we hope that this paper could inspire follow-up work on this topic.
label: concur

sentence: > [1] found that the network architecture for self-supervised learning can matter a lot, and that by using a ResNet architecture, performance of SSL methods can be significantly improved.
label: nonarg

sentence: Indeed, the paper mentioned by the reviewer shows that the performance of various self-supervised methods for ResNets does not degrade with the depth as it does for VGG and AlexNets due to the skip-connections.
label: nonarg

sentence: However, as ResNets have not been originally used to train the methods analyzed in our paper, we have stayed in the bounds that are required for fair comparisons and only used AlexNet.
label: nonarg

sentence: We agree with the reviewer that it would be good to check if ResNets, in general, can also be trained in such a manner (e.g. could global pooling destroy the signal?), so we are running an experiment on a ResNet-18 and will report results in the upcoming days.
label: concur

sentence: > Does the MonoGAN exhibit stable training dynamics comparable to training WGAN on CIFAR-10, or do the training dynamics change on the single-image data set?
label: nonarg

sentence: MonoGAN trained without any exploding gradients or other problems frequently encountered by GANs.
label: concur

sentence: As we have suggested in the paper, this might be due to the fact that image-patches from one image follow a simpler distribution than in-the-wild images of a complete dataset.
label: concur

sentence: [1] A. Dosovitskiy et al. "Discriminative unsupervised feature learning with exemplar convolutional neural networks." TPAMI 2015
label: nonarg

sentence: [2] R. Zhang et al. "Colorful image colorization." ECCV 2016.
label: nonarg

sentence: [3] P. Bojanowski et al. "Unsupervised learning by predicting noise." ICML 2017.
label: nonarg

sentence: [4] D. Pathak et al. “Context Encoders: Feature Learning by Inpainting". CVPR 2016.
label: nonarg

sentence: [5] M. Noroozi "Unsupervised learning for visual representations by solving jigsaw puzzles." ECCV 2016
label: nonarg

sentence: Thank you for your thoughtful review. We will address your concerns in turn.
label: nonarg

sentence: Q1: So you provide the general framework where somebody has to specify only the F?
label: nonarg

sentence: A1: Yes, and that is the motivation of this work, to avoid training new models for slightly different situations.
label: concur

sentence: Q2: The efficiency of the method is highly based on the ability of the GAN to approximate well the prior distribution of the noise-free images.
label: nonarg

sentence: A2: Yes, so we use WGAN-GP, a strong and elegant implementation, as our trained GAN.
label: concur

sentence: Q3: Is parameter Omega estimated individually for each degraded image?
label: nonarg

sentence: A3: Yes.
label: nonarg

sentence: Thank you again for your positive reviews which give me some confidence, I really appreciate it.
label: nonarg

sentence: Thank you for the review and accurate summary of our submission!
label: nonarg

sentence: > I am reluctant to give a higher score due to its incremental contribution.
label: nonarg

sentence: Specifically, the policy update in Dreamer resembles that of SVG (Heess et al., 2015), which also backpropagates re-parameterized gradients through a value function and a transition model.
label: nonarg

sentence: SVG clearly differs from Dreamer in that it only considers 1-step model predictions in SVG(1) or multi-step predictions without value function in SVG(∞).
label: dispute

sentence: SVG(0) does not use a dynamics model.
label: dispute

sentence: In addition, Dreamer propagates gradients through transitions in a learned features, making it effective for high-dimensional control tasks.
label: dispute

sentence: > Since the latent models are learned based on existing techniques, the paper presents an incremental contribution.
label: nonarg

sentence: Besides the important technical difference described above, we highlight the empirical performance of Dreamer.
label: dispute

sentence: A conclusion of the SVG paper was that the model did not yield substantial practical benefits beyond 1-step predictions.
label: dispute

sentence: We found it important to revisit this topic in the light of recent substantial improvements to dynamics models (see below).
label: nonarg

sentence: > Effectiveness on very long horizon trajectories: Simulating long-horizon trajectories with a probabilistic model is known to be unsuitable for model-based RL due to accumulated errors.
label: nonarg

sentence: This is an open issue in model-based RL.
label: nonarg

sentence: While current dynamics models still cannot accurately predict full episodes, this is rarely needed in practice.
label: dispute

sentence: Recent works successfully use learned dynamics for control from both proprioceptive inputs (Chua et al. 2018, Shyam et al. 2019, Wang & Ba 2019) and from images (Hafner et al. 2019, Zhang et al. 2019).
label: dispute

sentence: Dreamer shows that the relatively short model predictions (H=20) yield high-quality policy gradients, and that an additional value function in the latent space is effective for solving tasks that require longer-term credit assignment (e.g. with sparse rewards).
label: nonarg

sentence: Our experiments provide evidence that combination is effective in practice.
label: nonarg

sentence: > However, the issue still exists in Dreamer, since there seems to be an upper limit of effective horizon length (perhaps around 40, according to Figure 4).
label: nonarg

sentence: This horizon length is still short compared to the entire horizon length of many MDPs (e.g., 1000).
label: nonarg

sentence: I think this point should be discussed in the paper.
label: nonarg

sentence: That is, the issue still exists, and Dreamer is less effective with very long horizon.
label: nonarg

sentence: We address the challenge of long horizons not using long-term model predictions but by learning a value function that estimates the infinite sum of discounted future rewards.
label: dispute

sentence: Figure 4 in our submission shows that this gives Dreamer robustness to the imagination horizon compared to two baselines.
label: dispute

sentence: > Inapplicability to discrete controls:  One restriction of re-parameterized gradients is that the technique is not applicable to discrete random variables.
label: nonarg

sentence: This restriction exists in Dreamer, and the method cannot be applied to discrete control tasks unless approximation techniques such as Gumbel-softmax are used.
label: nonarg

sentence: Still, such approximations would make learning more challenging, especially with long-horizon backpropagation.
label: nonarg

sentence: This restriction should be noted in the paper.
label: nonarg

sentence: We applied Dreamer to environments with discrete actions using the DiCE estimator (Foerster et al. 2018) locally for the da/dμ and da/dσ derivatives.
label: concur

sentence: This was a drop-in replacement for the reparameterization estimator and slightly outperformed a Gumble-softmax actor.
label: concur

sentence: We find that with this 1 line change, Dreamer solves discrete action tasks of the Atari suite and a 3D DMLab environment.
label: concur

sentence: > There is no mention about variance of policy gradient estimates.
label: nonarg

sentence: Dreamer does not use any variance reduction technique, so the gradient estimates could have very large variance.
label: nonarg

sentence: Dreamer uses reparamterization gradients that already have low variance (Kingma & Welling 2013, Rezende et al. 2014); although see Miller et al. (2017).
label: dispute

sentence: Learning baselines for variance reduction is common for Reinforce estimators as used in A3C and PPO (Mnih et al. 2016, Schulman et al. 2017) but not for reparameterization estimators as used in Dreamer, SVG, and SAC (Heess et al. 2015, Haarnoja et al. 2018).
label: dispute

sentence: Regarding your first concern on the comparison with CW: In short, MarginAttack is able to achieve a higher attack success rate than CW AND a shorter running time.
label: concur

sentence: The paper may not make this point obvious enough probably because the curves are too thick to reveal the difference.
label: concur

sentence: To show this point clearly, we would like to refer you to the results in our response to reviewer 3, where we scanned through the number of binary search steps and measure the success rate and running time.
label: concur

sentence: As can be seen, MarginAttack has a higher success rate than all the versions of CW.
label: concur

sentence: There is a success-rate-efficiency tradeoff in CW, as a smaller binary search step number leads to a lower success rate.
label: concur

sentence: However, even with 10 binary search steps, CW is still unable to outperform MarginAttack in terms of success rate.
label: concur

sentence: On the other hand, with very small numbers of binary search steps, CW still runs slower than MarginAttack.
label: concur

sentence: Hope these results will clarify your major concern.
label: nonarg

sentence: Regarding your minor concern:
label: nonarg

sentence: In the theorem, we did not assume convexity.
label: concur

sentence: The assumption with the name 'convexity' is saying that the constraint set should not be 'too concave'.
label: concur

sentence: Please check the following figure where we listed what decision boundaries are permitted by our theorem and what not.
label: concur

sentence: https://docs.google.com/viewer?url=https://raw.githubusercontent.com/anon181018/iclr2019_rebuttal/master/figure2.pdf
label: concur

sentence: As can be seen, the convexity assumption permits a wide variety of decision boundaries.
label: concur

sentence: Among the few cases that it does not permit is the case where the decision boundary bends more than the L2 ball does.
label: concur

sentence: In this case, the critical point becomes a local maximum rather than a local minimum.
label: concur

sentence: Thank you for the instructive review!
label: nonarg

sentence: Our algorithm 1 minimizes the empirical learnable noise risk (Eq. 4), which does not assume that X_{t-1}^{(j)} follows a diagonal gaussian distribution.
label: dispute

sentence: Originally, to justify the I^u=1/2 \sum_l log(1+Var(X^(j)_{t-1,l})/ \eta_{j,l}^2) term used in our experiments for estimating mutual information, we used diagonal Gaussian assumption for X_{t-1}^(j) in the experiment.
label: dispute

sentence: In fact, a better way to justify this is to note that I^u provides an upper bound for the mutual information subject to the constraint of known variance of marginal distributions of X^(j)_{t-1}, and the upper bound is reached with the diagonal Gaussian distribution, as is proved in Appendix C in the revision.
label: dispute

sentence: Therefore, the assumption of diagonal Gaussian assumption is dropped for the experiments in the revision.
label: concur

sentence: Practitioners can choose to optimize an upper bound of the learnable noise risk for better efficiency (as is also used in the experiments in this paper), or use differentiable estimate of mutual information for better accuracy, as has also been pointed out in the paper.
label: concur

sentence: In the revision, we have also added a more detailed comparison with other methods in sections 4.2 and 4.3, showing the strength of our method.
label: concur

sentence: For example, in section 4.2, our method correctly identifies important causal arrows, while the four other comparison methods either have more false positives and false negatives, or completely fail to discover causal arrows.
label: concur

sentence: In section 4.3
label: nonarg

sentence: , we compare with the results in previous literature.
label: concur

sentence: We note that although all compared methods correctly identify the causal relations, our method have the advantage that the inferred causal strength does not decay with increasing history length (we also analyzed that in the original submission).
label: concur

sentence: We thank you for your constructive feedback.
label: nonarg

sentence: We reply to all reviews in a general response above.
label: nonarg

sentence: We thank the reviewer for the feedback.
label: nonarg

sentence: In the following, we address the comments individually:
label: nonarg

sentence: -  Comparison with conventional triplet methods using images and their corresponding RGB images
label: nonarg

sentence: We did not consider comparisons with conventional triplet approaches: the message of our paper was not to demonstrate the utility of ordinal embedding approaches over conventional (representation-based) triplet approaches.
label: dispute

sentence: It was rather to show that when input representations are NOT available, we provide a scalable approach to solve the ordinal embedding problem.
label: dispute

sentence: We agree with the reviewer that such a comparison would be possible but the experiments, we believe, would not reflect the message of the paper.
label: dispute

sentence: -  More synthetic experiments comparing the various ordinal embedding approaches
label: nonarg

sentence: There is a large literature that compares existing ordinal embedding approaches, and in order to not overload the figures, we had decided to just compare against the most popular traditional algorithms. But we can definitely add more comparisons in the revision of the paper.
label: concur

sentence: The “claim that the use of neural networks with discrete inputs can approximately solve NP-hard optimization problems”
label: nonarg

sentence: We would like to clarify that our claim was merely that we use neural networks to address ONE instance of an NP-hard optimization problem.
label: concur

sentence: We want to bring attention to the generic idea of using neural networks as optimization toolboxes to directly solve non-convex optimization objectives instead of merely for learning problems.
label: concur

sentence: We thank the reviewer for the evaluation.
label: nonarg

sentence: Please see our detailed response to several recurring issues at https://openreview.net/forum?id=Hkx-ii05FQ&noteId=HygFbNmL6X.
label: nonarg

sentence: In that response we address the following issues:
label: nonarg

sentence: (1) We emphasize fundamental differences between Cakewalk and CE.
label: nonarg

sentence: (2) How the sampling distribution should not be considered as a part of Cakewalk, and that it is mostly provided as an example, and a basis for the reported experiments.
label: nonarg

sentence: (3) The experiments include results two tasks.
label: nonarg

sentence: Nonetheless, it appears the paper doesn’t convey this clearly, and we suggest two possible ways how to update the paper in this regard.
label: nonarg

sentence: Next, we’ll try to provide some intuition as to why a sampling distribution that assumes independence between the different dimensions can be useful in some cases.
label: nonarg

sentence: The simple explanation is that in some problems the conditional expectation of the objective given that some x_i=j is much better than for other values x_i=k. In such cases, for each dimension the algorithm will tend to sample values which are useful to many possible solutions.
label: concur

sentence: In the clique problem for example, if some node i is part of a large clique, then sampling x_i=1 is likely to result in a good objective as there are many nodes that are connected to i, and the chance of not sampling any of them decreases with the clique size.
label: concur

sentence: In this way, over time the probability for sampling such nodes becomes higher, and the chance of sampling all of them together increases.
label: concur

sentence: Lastly, we note that these kind of factorized distributions have a long history of being useful  in machine learning.
label: concur

sentence: In a similar context to the one studied in the paper, such distributions have been studied by Rubinstein in his paper which discusses CE as an algorithm for combinatorial optimization, and in the classical bandit papers Exp3 is applied independently to several dimensions to study game theoretic problems.
label: concur

sentence: In different contexts, such distributions have also been used as naive mean field approximations in variational inference.
label: concur

sentence: We thank Reviewer 1 (R1) for their review and for asking interesting questions that helped us to understand where our paper may have been unclear.
label: nonarg

sentence: In our response below we will try our best to better explain our motivation for building and using SQOOP, as well as address R1’s other questions and concerns.
label: nonarg

sentence: A key concern that R1 expressed in their review is that we perform our study on the new SQOOP dataset, instead of using an available one (for example CLEVR or Abstract Scenes VQA).
label: nonarg

sentence: Though we appreciate the concern (it has spurred us to rethink and rephrase how we justify SQOOP) we still believe that the SQOOP dataset is the best choice for precisely testing our ideas.
label: dispute

sentence: We kindly invite R1 to consider the following arguments in favor of doing so:
label: nonarg

sentence: The goal of our study was to perform a thorough investigation of systematic generalization of language understanding models.
label: concur

sentence: To that end, we wanted a setup that is as simple as possible, while still being challenging by testing the ability to extend the relational reasoning learned to unseen combinations of seen words.
label: concur

sentence: We therefore choose to focus on simplest relational questions of the form XRY, as they also allow us to factor out challenges of discrete optimization in choosing the right module layout (required for Stochastic N2NMN).
label: concur

sentence: The simplicity is also useful because most models get to 100% accuracy on the training set of SQOOP, which allowed us to put aside any remaining optimization challenges and just focus our study on systematic generalization.
label: concur

sentence: In contrast, we find that the popular CLEVR dataset does not satisfy our requirements and if we did modify it sufficiently, we believe that it would only differ from SQOOP in the actual rendering and would not affect our conclusions.
label: concur

sentence: Though visually more complex, CLEVR has only 3 object types: cylinder, sphere and cube.
label: concur

sentence: Therefore, it would only allow for 3x4x3=36 different XRY relational questions.
label: concur

sentence: This is arguably not enough to sufficiently represent real world situations, and would definitely hinder our experiments.
label: concur

sentence: Specifically, we would not be able to sufficiently vary the difficulty of our generalization challenge when allowing 1,2,4,8 or 18 possible right hand-side objects in the questions (we clarify why splits with lower #rhs/lhs are more difficult than those with higher #rhs/lhs later in this response).
label: concur

sentence: Hence, we did not find the original CLEVR readily appropriate for our study.
label: dispute

sentence: We could, in theory, introduce new object types to CLEVR and rerender a new dataset in 3D using Blender (the renderer that was used to create CLEVR) with different lighting conditions and partial occlusions.
label: concur

sentence: Though enticing, we believe that such a 3D version of SQOOP would lead to exactly same conclusions, because the vision required to recognize the objects in the scene would still be rather trivial.
label: concur

sentence: The Ying and Yang dataset is clearly a valuable resource (and we thank the reviewer for the pointer), but we do not think it is readily suitable for the kind of study that we aim to perform.
label: dispute

sentence: The dataset, to the best of our understanding, uses crowd-sourced questions (as the questions are taken from Abstract VQA dataset, whose captions were entered by a human, according to the original VQA paper https://arxiv.org/pdf/1505.00468v6.pdf).
label: concur

sentence: Using crowd-sourced questions would not allow us to control our experiments at the level of precision that we wanted to achieve (e.g. we would not know the ground-truth layouts, it would be harder to construct splits of varying difficulty, etc.).
label: concur

sentence: As well, Abstract VQA contains only 50k scenes, and from our experience with SQOOP we know that this number would be not sufficient to rule out overfitting to training images as a factor.
label: concur

sentence: We thank R1 for their constructive suggestion to consider NMNs that form a DAG.
label: nonarg

sentence: We are currently investigating a chain-structured NMN with shortcuts from the output of the stem to each of the modules, and we will soon report these additional results in the upcoming revision of the paper.
label: concur

sentence: We hope that these results, combined with further qualitative investigations we are conducting, will answer the legitimate question of R1 as to why Chain-NMN performs so much worse than Tree-NMN.
label: concur

sentence: We acknowledge that the text of the paper can be improved to explain better why splits with lower #rhs/lhs are generally harder than those with higher #rhs/lhs, and we thank R1 for pointing this
label: concur

sentence: out
label: concur

sentence: Our reasoning is that lower #rhs/lhs are harder because the training admits more spurious solutions in them.
label: concur

sentence: In such spurious regimes models adapt to the specific lhs-rhs combinations from the training and can not generalize to unseen lhs-rhs combinations (i.e. generalizing from questions about “A” in relation with “B” to “A” in relation to “D” (as in #rhs/lhs=1) is more difficult than generalizing from questions about “A” in relation to “B” and “C” to the same “A” in relation to “D” (as in #rhs/lhs=2).
label: concur

sentence: We will update the paper to be more explicit in explaining these considerations.
label: concur

sentence: We would like to conclude our response by replying to the higher-level concern of R1 that the findings of our study may not “generalize to other more complex datasets where the network layout NMN might be more complex, the number of modules and type of modules might also be more”.
label: nonarg

sentence: While we fully agree that more complex datasets with more complex questions would bring new challenges, these are ones we purposely put aside (such as the general unavailability of ground-truth layouts for vanilla NMN, the need to consider an exponentially large set of possible layouts for Stochastic N2NMN, etc.) We believe that it is highly valuable for the research community to know what happens in the simple ideal case of SQOOP, where we can precisely test our specific generalization criterion.
label: concur

sentence: This knowledge (e.g. the superiority of trees to chains, the sensitivity of layout induction to initialization, the emergence of spurious parameterization in end-to-end learning), will guide researchers in choosing, designing and troubleshooting their models, as they now know what to expect modulo the optimization challenges that they may face.
label: concur

sentence: The field of language understanding with deep learning is not easily amenable to mathematical theoretical investigations and, with that in mind, rigorous minimalistic studies like ours are arguably very important.
label: concur

sentence: To some extent, they play the role of the former: they inform researcher intuition and lay a solid foundation for scientific dialogue.
label: concur

sentence: We purposely traded breadth for depth in our investigations, and we will go even deeper in the additional experiments that the upcoming revision will contain.
label: concur

sentence: We believe that the total of our results makes a complete conference paper.
label: concur

sentence: All that said, we would welcome specific suggestions of additional experiments that we could carry out in order to better validate our claims.
label: nonarg

sentence: We hope that this response has clarified to R1 what our paper was insufficiently clear about. A new revision with additional experiments and fixed typos will soon be uploaded to OpenReview, and we hope that R1 takes this response and the changes that we will make to the paper into account.
label: concur

sentence: We thank the reviewer for the valuable review comments and suggestions! Please find our point-by-point response as follows.
label: nonarg

sentence: Q1: Is there only 1 adversarial party?
label: nonarg

sentence: A1: There is only one adversarial party in centralized attack.
label: concur

sentence: But we make sure that the total injected triggers (e.g., modified pixels) of DBA attackers is close to and even less than that of the centralized attacker.
label: concur

sentence: We stressed this setup in Section 3.2.
label: concur

sentence: That is, the ratio of the global trigger of DBA pixels to the centralized is 0.992 for LOAN, 0.964 for MNIST, 0.990 for CIFAR and 0.991 for Tiny-imagenet.
label: concur

sentence: Q2: What’s the result for centralized attacks with the same number of scaling times as DBA, but each update includes 1/4 number of poisoning samples?
label: nonarg

sentence: A2: Following your suggestion, we conducted two sets of new experiments.
label: concur

sentence: 1. Change the poison ratio into 1/4: We decrease the fraction of backdoored samples added per training batch into 1/4.
label: nonarg

sentence: 2. Change the data size into 1/4: We divide the local dataset into 4 parts and use 1/4 dataset for each update and keep the poison ratio unchanged.
label: nonarg

sentence: We have included the results and discussion in Appendix A.4 of the revised version.
label: concur

sentence: Q3: If the decomposition is also useful for trigger patterns that are not necessarily regular shapes?
label: nonarg

sentence: A3: It’s also useful for irregular shape triggers.
label: nonarg

sentence: 1. We study the irregular pixel logo ‘ICLR’ for three image datasets.
label: nonarg

sentence: Specifically, we use ‘ICLR’ as the global trigger pattern and decompose it into ‘I’, ‘C’, ‘L’, ‘R’ for local triggers.
label: nonarg

sentence: 2. We also use the physical trigger glasses (Chen et al.,2017) on Tiny-imagenet and decomposed the pattern into four parts.
label: nonarg

sentence: The results are in Appendix A.3 of our revised version.
label: concur

sentence: DBA is also more effective and this conclusion is consistent in different colors of glasses.
label: nonarg

sentence: Q4: Can the authors show concrete examples on how the attacks are generated? The details are especially unclear on LOAN.
label: nonarg

sentence: A4: We note that we have mentioned our attack formulation and algorithm in Section 2.2;
label: concur

sentence: We have also provided more details about LOAN dataset and how we attack in Appendix A.1.
label: concur

sentence: We thank the reviewer for the effort, however we believe there is a mis-understanding.
label: nonarg

sentence: As for the synthetic curves experiment, we updated the paper with a justification.
label: concur

sentence: This task, while simple, showcases the ability of Transformer to model a distribution over curves of similar shape to real training curves with varying speeds of convergence.
label: concur

sentence: It has been designed so it is easy to quantify the diversity of generated curves and the fit between the distribution generated by the model and the real one.
label: concur

sentence: Furthermore, we included two additional tasks, attesting to the ability of Transformer to model a wide range of distributions over training curves.
label: concur

sentence: We also updated the citation of the paper you mentioned with an arxiv URL.
label: concur

sentence: We still believe that while focusing on the synthetic task the reviewer might have missed the main point of the paper, namely that time-series forecasting with Transformer works really well, at least in the context of modeling deep learning dynamics.
label: concur

sentence: The general problem has been studied in the community for many decades and we believe that we made significant progress, so we kindly encourage the reviewer to reconsider their assessment of our contributions.
label: nonarg

sentence: We are thankful for the reviewer 2 to provide us with his/her feedback,
label: nonarg

sentence: The reviewer mentioned: "the interpolation mechanism is also too simple":
label: nonarg

sentence: We would like to highlight that despite the simplicity of interpolated samples, there has been demonstrated the effectiveness of using such samples on developing more regularized and generalized neural networks (Zhang et al, 2018) as well as on making them more secure
label: dispute

sentence: (Zhao et. al. 2018)
label: dispute

sentence: Thus, we believe that simplicity does not necessarily lead to ineffectiveness.
label: dispute

sentence: The reviewer mentioned “many hidden assumptions on the images source or the base classier”:
label: nonarg

sentence: As this statement is not clear for us, we would appreciate if the reviewer could elaborate more on it.
label: nonarg

sentence: The only assumption we made is on the fact that the out-distribution samples should be statistically and semantically different than the in-distribution samples.
label: dispute

sentence: Then among such out-distribution sets, we propose a measurement for identifying the most representative one among those available.
label: dispute

sentence: The reviewer stated "There exists more principled approaches for *selecting* out-distribution images that has not considered here like those based on uncertainty estimation or recently proposed direct out-distribution detectors":
label: nonarg

sentence: While there are the approaches that aim to detect out-distribution sets, they have not been designed for the selection purposes as we do.
label: dispute

sentence: By mentioning this statement, if the reviewer means the missing of some principled approaches like ODIN in our comparisons, we would like to inform the inclusion of ODIN results in the revised version of the paper.
label: concur

sentence: We agree that the prediction from CSLB features is particularly interesting, and we are currently working on improving this further by interpolating to other objects in a semi-supervised manner (similar to what was proposed by the reviewer).

sentence: For the present work, we focused on synset embeddings because they represent a closer match to the meaning of each individual object than word embeddings would and provide a one-to-one match for the meanings.

sentence: For example, our list contains four different meanings for the object named by the word “baton”, referring to (1) an item in relay races, (2) in twirling, (3) a weapon used by police, and (4) an item used by a musical conductor.
label: concur

sentence: Due to the novelty of this line of research, to our knowledge there are no other synset embeddings available than the ones we used, and we included both a 50d dense and a 300d dense version.
label: concur

sentence: In addition, we would have liked to include sparse positive synset embeddings as a reference, however those are currently not available; for that reason, we included NNSE word embeddings instead.
label: concur

sentence: In the future, we would like to add sparse positive synset embeddings and test their interpretability relative to our similarity embedding.
label: concur

sentence: We hope this will underline the unique contribution of a behavior-based similarity embedding presented here.
label: concur

sentence: In addition, we would like to thank the reviewer for their idea on how to extend the embedding.
label: concur

sentence: Indeed, we are currently working on predicting similarities for other concepts and images from pretrained synset vectors and activations in deep convolutional neural networks.
label: concur

sentence: However, this effort is still in its early stages and beyond the scope of the present work.
label: concur

sentence: We very much appreciate your valuable comments, efforts and times on our paper.
label: nonarg

sentence: Our responses for all your questions are provided below. Our major revisions in the new draft are colored by red.
label: nonarg

sentence: Q1. More related works
label: nonarg

sentence: We updated the introduction by including more recent works [1, 2, 3, 4, 5] related to deep learning with noisy labels.
label: concur

sentence: In the previous draft, we only included the relevant literature which involves a single network/classifier.
label: nonarg

sentence: The updated related works utilize multiple networks, e.g., an ensemble of classifiers or meta-learning model.
label: nonarg

sentence: We also added new experimental results for them in Table 4 of the revised draft, as we mentioned in our common response to all reviewers.
label: concur

sentence: Thank you very much for the suggestions.
label: nonarg

sentence: Q2. Comparison with VAT [6].
label: nonarg

sentence: We remark that a targeted setting of VAT [6] is different from ours in that it is designed for improving the performance on semi-supervised learning, while our main goal is handling noisy labels in the training dataset.
label: dispute

sentence: Due to this, we skip the comparison with VAT.
label: dispute

sentence: Instead, as we mentioned in our common response to all reviewers, we consider more training baselines (such as MentorNet [2] and Co-teaching [3]) focusing on handling noisy labels, and show that our inference method can improve all of them.
label: nonarg

sentence: Q3. L-FBGS adversarial attacks [8].
label: nonarg

sentence: We remark that L-FBGS [8] is known to fail easily due to the near-zero gradient of loss function [7].
label: dispute

sentence: Instead, we consider CW attack [7] which is known to be much stronger.
label: concur

sentence: We agree that our most surprising results are for SGD under constant step budgets or unlimited epoch budgets.
label: concur

sentence: However the behaviour of SGD under constant epoch budgets has generated a lot of debate in the literature in recent years, and we felt it was important to address this simple case first.
label: concur

sentence: We agree that some of the observations in sections 2 and 3 have already been made in previous work, however there are also several important differences:
label: concur

sentence: 1. Ma, Bassily and Belkin also introduced the notion of two regimes, however their theory holds for convex losses in the interpolating regime.
label: dispute

sentence: We will discuss their contribution explicitly in the updated text.
label: dispute

sentence: Our discussion in section 2 clarifies why the two regimes arise in practical deep learning models for which these conditions may not hold.
label: dispute

sentence: Our paper is the first to relate the two regimes of SGD to the popular analogy between SGD and stochastic differential equations (SDEs).
label: dispute

sentence: As we show in later sections, this perspective is crucial to understanding the influence of batch size and learning rate on test accuracy.
label: dispute

sentence: A common criticism of this analogy is that SGD noise is not Gaussian when the batch size is small.
label: dispute

sentence: To our knowledge, we are the first to show that the analogy between SGD and SDEs holds for non-Gaussian short-tailed noise (appendix B).
label: dispute

sentence: 3. We clarify the differences to some other recent papers in our reply to reviewer 1.
label: dispute

sentence: Two reviewers complained that it was difficult to tell from the text which contributions are novel and which also appear in previous works.
label: concur

sentence: We apologise for this.
label: concur

sentence: It was not our intention and we will edit sections 1 and 2 to ensure that this is resolved and that the above points are reflected in the text.
label: concur

sentence: Turning to our generalization experiments in sections 4 and 5.
label: concur

sentence: We agree that many authors have proposed that SGD noise enhances generalization.
label: concur

sentence: Most notably, Keskar et al. argued that large minibatches perform worse than small minibatches on the test set, even when both achieve similar performance on the training set.
label: concur

sentence: However their experiments do not provide convincing evidence for this claim, because they tuned the learning rate with small batches and then used the same learning rate value with large batches.
label: dispute

sentence: A convincing experiment should independently tune the learning rate at all batch sizes under a constant step budget, and it should use a realistic learning rate decay schedule.
label: dispute

sentence: Indeed, Shallue et al. recently argued that no existing paper has provided convincing evidence that small batch sizes generalize better than large batch sizes under constant step budgets, and they state in their abstract ‘We find no evidence that larger batch sizes degrade out-of-sample performance’.
label: dispute

sentence: Meanwhile, Zhang et al. argued that optimization in deep learning is well described by a noisy quadratic model which predicts that increasing the batch size should always enhance performance under constant step budgets.
label: dispute

sentence: To our knowledge, our experimental results in section 4 are the first to provide convincing evidence that very large minibatches do perform worse than small batch sizes on the test set, even under constant step budgets and when the learning rate is independently tuned.
label: dispute

sentence: We believe this is an important contribution.
label: dispute

sentence: Meanwhile, our results in section 5 suggest that SGD has an optimal temperature early in training which promotes generalization and is independent of the epoch budget.
label: dispute

sentence: In response to the reviewer’s specific comments:
label: nonarg

sentence: 1) Looking at Figure 1c, while the optimal learning rate at 8k with Momentum is 4, the error bars at this batch size range from 4 to 32.
label: concur

sentence: These error bars can be very large in the curvature regime, precisely because the optimal learning rate is close to instability.
label: concur

sentence: 2) Yes, Momentum will help under constant step budgets if the batch size is large, since it enables us to achieve larger effective learning rates which are beneficial for generalization.
label: concur

sentence: We will add additional experiments to the text to clarify this.
label: concur

sentence: 3) We will clarify the meaning of warm up, epoch budget and step budget as requested.
label: concur

sentence: Thank you for your appreciation of our work!
label: nonarg

sentence: We would like to thank Reviewer 2 for their review and constructive suggestions.
label: nonarg

sentence: Our responses inline:
label: nonarg

sentence: >Discussions sometimes lack depth or are absent.
label: nonarg

sentence: -We have added an additional section (Appendix G) expanding on our discussion and providing additional insight into the observed instabilities.
label: concur

sentence: >For example, it is unclear to me why some larger models are not amenable to truncation.
label: nonarg

sentence: Besides visible artifacts, what does it mean? Why does a smoother G reduces those artifacts?
label: nonarg

sentence: -Truncation introduces a train-test disparity in G’s inputs--at sampling time, G is given a distribution it has effectively never seen in training.
label: concur

sentence: The observation that imposing orthogonality constraints improves amenability to truncation is empirical.
label: concur

sentence: Our suspicion is that if G is not encouraged to be “smooth” in some sense, then it is likely that G will only properly generate images given points from the untruncated distribution.
label: concur

sentence: We hypothesize that models which are not amenable end up learning mappings which, when given truncated noise, either attenuate or amplify certain activation pathways, leading to extreme output values (hence the observed saturation artifacts).
label: concur

sentence: We speculate that encouraging G’s filters to have minimum pairwise cosine similarity means that, when exposed to distribution shift, the network’s features are less correlated and less likely to align and amplify an activation path it would otherwise have learned to scale properly.
label: concur

sentence: >Were samples from those networks better without using truncation? Why would this be?
label: nonarg

sentence: -Samples from those networks without truncation do not have measurably different quality, and their training metrics (losses, singular values) show no differences.
label: concur

sentence: Aside from empirically testing each network individually for amenability to truncation, we found no other way to check for that amenability.
label: concur

sentence: > Authors report how wider networks perform best, and how deeper networks degrade performance.
label: nonarg

sentence: Again, discussions are lacking, and it doesn’t seem the authors tried to understand why such behaviors were shown.
label: nonarg

sentence: Even though this is mostly an empirical investigation, I think some more efforts should be put in understanding and explaining why some of those behaviors are shown, as I think it can bootstrap future work more easily.
label: dispute

sentence: -We are wary of explanations for which we do not have evidence.
label: concur

sentence: For each of the modifications introduced in Section 3, we offer a succinct conjecture as to why that change improves performance, but we are not aware of any existing reliable, informative metric which we could employ to understand or trace the source of each observed behavior, particularly with respect to GAN stability or performance.
label: concur

sentence: Regarding depth vs width: This paper is empirical, and we only briefly experimented with increasing depth analogously to increasing width.
label: concur

sentence: While increasing width provided an immediate measurable benefit, increasing depth did not.
label: concur

sentence: We felt that it was better to report the results of this brief investigation than to omit it for a lack of investigatory depth.
label: concur

sentence: > In Section 3.1 : “Across runs in Table 1, we observe that without Orthogonal Regularization, only 16% of models are amenable to truncation compared to 60% with Orthogonal Regularization.” For me, this is not particularly clear.
label: nonarg

sentence: Is this something the reader should understand from Table 1?
label: nonarg

sentence: -This means that of all the models we trained for the study presented in Table 1 which did not use Orthogonal Regularization, only 16% were amenable to truncation.
label: concur

sentence: Of all the models which we trained for the study presented in Table 2 which did use Orthogonal Regularization, 60% were amenable to truncation.
label: concur

sentence: This is not reflected in Table 1, which is merely a presentation of how the introduced modifications impact performance.
label: concur

sentence: >I question the choice of sections chosen to be in the main paper/appendices.
label: nonarg

sentence: I greatly appreciated the negative results reported in the main text as well as in the appendices and this has significant value.
label: nonarg

sentence: However, as this is to me mostly a detailed empirical investigation and presentation of high-performance GANs on large scales, I would be likely to share this with colleagues who want to tackle similar problems.
label: nonarg

sentence: In this case, if future readers limit themselves to the main text, I think it can have more value to present some content form Appendix B and C than to have more than a full page on stability investigations and attempted tricks that turned out not to be used to reach maximal performance.
label: nonarg

sentence: However I do not want to discourage publishing of negative results, and I definitely wish to see this investigation in the paper, but I merely question the positioning of such information.
label: nonarg

sentence: With regard to my first negative point above about the lack of discussions, it seems the analysis of Section 4 is disproportionate compared to other places.
label: nonarg

sentence: -We appreciate this suggestion.
label: nonarg

sentence: While we recognize that this paper generally has a strong focus on implementation details, we felt that this instability was one of the most salient behaviors we observed, and that future work would be best served by presenting our investigations and attempts to understand its source, even if these methods did not improve performance.
label: dispute

sentence: The information in Appendix B and C is intended to be of interest to those who want to reproduce our experiments, so it largely comprises hyperparameters and architectural details that we felt were not necessary to understand the main results of the paper.
label: concur

sentence: >In Appendix F, Figure 20 d), the title seems wrong. It seems to report sigma^2 values, but the title says “losses”.
label: nonarg

sentence: -Thanks! This was indeed an error, which we’ve corrected in the updated draft.
label: concur

sentence: >I would also be curious to see the proposed techniques applied on simpler datasets. Can this be useful for someone having less compute power and working on something similar to CelebA?
label: nonarg

sentence: -The goal of this work is to explore GANs at large scale; the exploration of small or medium scale models would indeed be interesting for another study.
label: concur

sentence: Having said that, we do evaluate BigGAN on conditional CIFAR-10 (mentioned briefly in Appendix C.2) and obtain an IS of 9.22 and an FID of 14.73 without truncation, which to our knowledge are better than any published results.
label: concur

sentence: Thank you very much for your constructive comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: First, with respect to baselines, we have updated the results tables to include the additional baselines mentioned, as well as runs for VAT(+EntMin) with lower numbers of labels on CIFAR-10.
label: concur

sentence: After updating these baselines, we note that our method still achieves state-of-the-art performance in the regime where 1000 and 2000 labels are used for training on CIFAR-10, with and without data augmentation.
label: dispute

sentence: We have also updated the text to tone down the claims.
label: concur

sentence: In addition, we note that the highest performance in many of the mentioned baselines (and with VAT) are obtained with a combination of multiple approaches.
label: dispute

sentence: Defining the best combination of techniques to achieve the highest performance is an interesting direction of future work; our preliminary experiments combining Mean Teacher with manifold regularization have shown some improvements and we will include the results in the final version of the paper.
label: concur

sentence: Second, with respect to novelty, we would like to re-iterate our contributions since they may not have been clear.
label: nonarg

sentence: First, while manifold regularization has been explored in (Kumar et al 2017) and (Qi et al 2018), we proposed an efficient and effective approximation of manifold regularization that is far easier to compute than the involved method in (Kumar et al 2017).
label: dispute

sentence: Moreover, we point out issues with the standard finite difference approximation to the Jacobian regularization and propose a solution to this problem by ignoring the magnitude of the gradient and using only the direction information.
label: dispute

sentence: Moreover, we showed manifold regularization provides significant improvements to image quality and linked it to gradient penalties used for stabilizing GAN training, which were not shown by (Qi et al 2018).
label: dispute

sentence: We did try to use spectral normalization but did not observe any gains for semi-supervised learning.
label: concur

sentence: Finally we would like to emphasize the conceptual differences between our method and other smoothing methods like spectral normalization - such methods perform isotropic regularization, whilst ours performs anisotropic smoothing along the manifold directions of generated data-points.
label: concur

sentence: We showed through experiments using (isotropic) ambient regularization that anisotropic regularization is more beneficial in the case of semi-supervised learning.
label: concur

sentence: Regarding comment 1: Thanks for recognizing the merit of our idea.
label: nonarg

sentence: As also mentioned by Reviewer #2, the proposed MAD implicitly assumes that classifiers in the competition are reasonably accurate.
label: dispute

sentence: Otherwise, the selected counterexamples may be less meaningful.
label: dispute

sentence: We will make this assumption explicit in the revised manuscript.
label: concur

sentence: From this perspective (and other reasons mentioned in the discussion section), MAD should be viewed as complementary to, rather than a replacement for, the conventional accuracy comparison for image classification.
label: concur

sentence: When two classifiers perform at a reasonable level and achieve very close accuracy numbers (e.g., VGG16BN and ResNet34 on ImageNet validation set), MAD provides the most efficient way of differentiating the two models by maximizing their discrepancies over a large-scale image set.
label: concur

sentence: We want to emphasize that MAD is especially useful on image classification tasks where most cutting-edge classifiers achieve very close performance.
label: concur

sentence: In these situations, the MAD competition ranking, which is obtained by evaluating on corner examples searched from web-scale unlabeled dataset, is more convincing than something like 1% accuracy advantage on the validation set.
label: concur

sentence: For problem domains where there are few sufficiently accurate models, we may still apply the underlying principle behind MAD to create adaptive test sets such that the strengths and weaknesses of the models are most easily revealed.
label: concur

sentence: In those scenarios, we conjecture that we need increase k to a reasonably larger number, thus at the cost of efficiency.
label: concur

sentence: Regarding comment 2: Thanks for the comment.
label: nonarg

sentence: As long as two (or multiple) models differ (even in slightly different ways), MAD provides the highly efficient way of spotting such differences by exploring a large-scale unlabelled dataset.
label: dispute

sentence: However, these differences are less likely to be revealed using a fixed and small test set (i.e., they will probably have the same accuracy numbers as models to be compared are very similar and are biased in similar ways).
label: dispute

sentence: For the extreme case that two models are exactly the same (i.e, they are biased in identical ways and make identical prediction errors), both MAD and traditional accuracy-based methods will draw the same conclusion - the two models have the same performance.
label: dispute

sentence: Accuracy-based evaluation methods arrive at this conclusion by comparing model predictions with ground truth labels and outputting the same accuracy numbers.
label: dispute

sentence: In contrast, MAD arrives at the same conclusion without any human labeling since the set S for subjective testing is empty.
label: dispute

sentence: So in this extreme case, both MAD and accuracy fail to compare those two models.
label: dispute

sentence: In summary, to reliably compare the relative performance of computational models, all evaluation methodologies (including MAD) rely on the assumption that the models to be compared should be diverse to a certain extent, and the proposed MAD makes this assumption more explicit.
label: nonarg

sentence: In fact, MAD makes the best use of model discrepancies (even if models are biased in very similar but not identical ways) to rank the model performance.
label: nonarg

sentence: As a matter of fact, based on our experiments, we find that state-of-the-art ImageNet classifiers do have their own biases. (See figure 8 in the appendix.)
label: nonarg

sentence: Regarding comment 3: Thanks for the excellent question.
label: nonarg

sentence: We believe that the parameter k is task-dependent.
label: concur

sentence: For problem domains where there are reasonably accurate models (e.g., imageNet classification in our example), we may obtain a stable ranking with a relative small k (e.g., k=15 in the imageNet classification example).
label: concur

sentence: For problem domains where there are no good models, we may increase k to the limit of human labeling budget in order to obtain reasonable performance comparison.
label: concur

sentence: Regarding comment 4: Thanks for the comment.
label: nonarg

sentence: In our current setting, we restrict the dataset D to the domain of interest that contain natural images of mainly 200 classes.
label: concur

sentence: However, as the construction of D is noisy and coarse, D contains plenty of open-set images, which do not belong to any class of interest.
label: concur

sentence: Since we do not perform any manually data screening at this stage, some of the open-set images may even be selected to construct the dataset S.
label: concur

sentence: This means that although the selected open-set image is out of the domain of interest, the associated two classifiers make different, high-confident (with threshold set to 0.8), but incorrect predictions (Case III).
label: concur

sentence: As a result, we consider it as a strong counterexample of the two classifiers.
label: concur

sentence: Note that this situation rarely happens, at least in our experiments because the competing classifiers tend to give open-set images low-confidence, and therefore are automatically filtered out.
label: concur

sentence: We agree with the reviewer that selecting images that contain only one salient object requires a lot of human effort.
label: concur

sentence: So we did not eliminate Case I. It turns out that keeping Case I does not seem to affect the comparison and analysis of competing models.
label: concur

sentence: We thank the reviewer for a detailed review.

sentence: We agree with the reviewer that a uniqueness result based on the axioms is desirable, but we don’t have it.
label: concur

sentence: While we’re able to show that the paths at the input and at the hidden layer must be coupled (i.e. non-oblivious), we just don’t understand the space of non-oblivious methods that well.
label: concur

sentence: Mathematically, we don’t have a handle on how the path at the hidden layer can vary as the network below the hidden layer is changed.
label: concur

sentence: Partition consistency is the only axiom about the network below the hidden layer, but it is not applicable to all networks.
label: concur

sentence: We probably need another axiom to prove uniqueness.
label: concur

sentence: Note, that regarding the methodology there were some misunderstandings (which we try to avoid for future readers in the revised version).

sentence: (1) The equations are indeed very related.
label: concur

sentence: Note however, that In a standard Bayesian neural network (BNN), one would assume that \theta is a global random variable (i.e. does not depend on input x), whereas in the CDN, we assume that \theta depends on x and is thus a local random variable.
label: concur

sentence: Furthermore, in a Bayesian setting p(theta|...) would play the role of a approximate posterior, which would require variational inference (VI), and thus a different objective,  to estimate it.
label: concur

sentence: (2) In Equation (4) we followed with  p(D | \psi) a standard notation for \sum_n p(y_n | x_n; \psi) (i.e. summation of Equation (3) wrt all data in D) which also can be found e.g. in the work of Graves (2011) [4] and Blundell et al. (2015) [5].
label: concur

sentence: The objective we introduce for CDNs differs from the ELBO-based objective in VI in the way the logarithm is placed in the first term of the objective: in the ELBO we have a logarithm inside the expectation, while the logarithm is outside the expectation in the CDN objective (note however, that the sample-based approximations get equivalent if only one sample is used).
label: concur

sentence: Furthermore, in the ELBO we have a fixed value of \lambda = 1.
label: concur

sentence: We added a new Section 4 in the revised version of the paper discussing these differences.
label: concur

sentence: Moreover, we investigated the impact of the different objectives empirically and found that the CDN-based objective led to significantly better results, as shown in the newly added Section 6.4 in the revised manuscript.
label: concur

sentence: (3) Indeed we need the probabilistic version of hypernetworks to implement the model we described in Equation (3).

sentence: We would like to thank Reviewer 1 for their review and constructive suggestions.
label: nonarg

sentence: Our responses inline:
label: nonarg

sentence: >Can you elaborate more on why BatchNorm statistics are computed across all devices as opposed to per-device? Was this crucial for best performance?
label: nonarg

sentence: -The primary reason is to ensure that training is invariant to the per-device batch size.
label: concur

sentence: When scaling from resolution 128x128 to 256x256, we increase the number of devices but maintain the same overall batch size, reducing the per-device batch size.
label: concur

sentence: Cross-replica BatchNorm ensures that the smaller per-device batch size does not affect training.
label: concur

sentence: Switching to per-device BatchNorm at 128x128 results in a performance drop, albeit not a crippling one: for a model which would otherwise get an IS of 92 and an FID of 9.5, switching to per-device BatchNorm results in an IS of 78 and FID of 13.
label: concur

sentence: >It is not clear if provided analysis for large-scale GANs apply for small-medium sized GANs.
label: nonarg

sentence: Providing such analysis would be also helpful for the community.
label: nonarg

sentence: -The goal of this work is to explore GANs at large scale; the exploration of small or medium scale models would indeed be interesting for another study.
label: dispute

sentence: Having said that, we do evaluate BigGAN on conditional CIFAR-10 (mentioned briefly in Appendix C.2) and obtain an IS of 9.22 and an FID of 14.73 without truncation, which to our knowledge are better than any published results.
label: nonarg

sentence: >How do you see the impact of the suggested techniques on tackling harder data-modalities for GANs, e.g. text or sequential data in general?
label: nonarg

sentence: -Any of the proposed techniques could be applied to standard GANs for text or other sequential data in principle, but we have not experimented with these applications ourselves.
label: concur

sentence: We thank the referee for finding our paper clearly written and in an interesting domain.
label: nonarg

sentence: 1. We are not training Restricted Boltzmann Machines (RBMs), but Boltzmann machines where the hidden units can be fully connected.
label: dispute

sentence: We have shown in our experiments (see Fig. 3) that using a single RBM as a pre-processor will not result in increased adversarial resistance.
label: nonarg

sentence: A comparison of mean field training vs. constrastive divergence for RBMs has been made by [III,IV].
label: nonarg

sentence: Nevertheless, we have added a comparison between our method and the exact solution for a small Boltzmann machine of 16 units in the appendix.
label: concur

sentence: While we don't claim that this explains the performance of the method under all circumstances, it gives an indication of how well it works.
label: nonarg

sentence: We agree that a more thorough study of the training method would be desirable but in this article we are concentrating on reporting the results on increased adversarial resistance.
label: nonarg

sentence: We believe that these results should be interesting to the community even if some doubts about the training procedure remain.
label: nonarg

sentence: Lastly, we want to obtain a differentiable building block that can be used in standard neural nets.
label: nonarg

sentence: The unrolling of the mean field iterations (see Fig. 1) provides a straightforward to achieve this.
label: nonarg

sentence: Propagating a gradient through a sampling based building block, while possible, would be considerably harder.
label: nonarg

sentence: 2. In [III,IV] the authors have succesfully used a mean field approximation beyond the trivial first order to train RBMs.
label: nonarg

sentence: In [II] a first order approximation is used.
label: nonarg

sentence: In our approach we use the approximation up to fourth order in the coupling J.
label: nonarg

sentence: 3. The approach of the authors in [III,IV] and also our approach is based on free energy.
label: nonarg

sentence: The systematic expansion of the free energy in the coupling constant forms the basis of our approach.
label: nonarg

sentence: 4. D is calculated as the relative entropy over a batch of 10000 examples.
label: concur

sentence: The reference probabilities are taken to be uniform and the model probabilities are calculated according to the procedure outlined in section 2.
label: concur

sentence: Due to the approximations involved it is possible that the sum of the model probabilities exceeds one.
label: concur

sentence: In this case we rescale the unclamped free energy to limit the total probability to one.
label: concur

sentence: We have added a note to that effect to the article.
label: concur

sentence: 5. We have included a comparison to the, to our knowledge, currently most adversarially resistant model on MNIST.
label: concur

sentence: Since our results are derived for MNIST we can only compare to methods in the literature that are evaluated on MNIST.
label: nonarg

sentence: We acknowledge that other methods perform very well on more sophisticated tasks and have added a reference.
label: nonarg

sentence: 6. While we have not explicitely labelled white box and black box attacks we are using a strong white box attack (gradient based) and the, to our knowledge, strongest black box attack (boundary method).
label: concur

sentence: We have added the labels in the text and Table 1 to make this more clear.
label: concur

sentence: 7. We have added some more attacks on the most robust model.
label: concur

sentence: We completely agree that more experiments on other datasets are needed to show the universality of the method.
label: dispute

sentence: Due to the computational complexity this will need to remain a topic for a follow up article.
label: concur

sentence: [I] Seyed-Mohsen Moosavi-Dezfooli, Ashish Shrivastava, Oncel Tuzel: Divide, Denoise, and Defend against Adversarial Attacks. arXiv 1802.06806 (2018).
