sentence: Thank you very much for your supportive remark! We are happy that the writing is clear to you. Below we provide additional comments regarding your questions.
label: concur

sentence: 1). Low-rank assumption:
label: nonarg

sentence: This work was primarily motivated by the observation that many systems exhibit strong relationship among states and actions, governed by potentially simple dynamics.
label: concur

sentence: This might eventually lead to structures within the optimal solution.
label: concur

sentence: We hope that this empirical study would motivate further theoretical analysis on structures within the community.
label: concur

sentence: Below are some thoughts on the potential theoretical motivation for this assumption:
label: concur

sentence: a) It is possible that the states and actions in consideration have some latent variable representations.
label: concur

sentence: If the optimal Q function is a piecewise analytic function on the latent variables, then there are works arguing the approximately low-rank property of the resulting matrix [1].
label: concur

sentence: b) There are theoretical works in RL and Markov process that assume that the transition kernel can be decomposed to a low-dimensional feature representation [2,3].
label: concur

sentence: These assumptions on the transition kernel may lead to low-rank optimal Q matrices.
label: concur

sentence: c) For continuous problems, theoretical analysis often needs to assume some sort of smoothness in the Q function [4,5].
label: concur

sentence: It is possible that such smoothness in the Q function will result in a low-rank Q matrix when evaluated at finite but fine enough discretized grid.
label: concur

sentence: [1] Udell, Madeleine, and Alex Townsend. "Why Are Big Data Matrices Approximately Low Rank?." SIAM Journal on Mathematics of Data Science 1.1 (2019): 144-160.
label: concur

sentence: [2] Yang, Lin, and Mengdi Wang. "Sample-Optimal Parametric Q-Learning Using Linearly Additive Features." International Conference on Machine Learning. 2019.
label: concur

sentence: [3] Sun, Yifan, et al. "Learning low-dimensional state embeddings and metastable clusters from time series data." Neural Information Processing Systems 2019.
label: concur

sentence: [4] Yang, Zhuora, Yuchen Xie, and Zhaoran Wang. "A theoretical analysis of deep Q-learning." arXiv preprint arXiv:1901.00137(2019).
label: concur

sentence: [5] Shah, Devavrat, and Qiaomin Xie. "Q-learning with nearest neighbors." Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems. 2018.
label: concur

sentence: 2). Dynamical manner for the number of incomplete observations and whether the strategy can be adapted to the nature of the problem:
label: nonarg

sentence: This is a great point and definitely an interesting future direction.
label: concur

sentence: In the current work, it is not immediately that one could easily detect the rank and adapt the algorithm in a principled manner.
label: concur

sentence: As one practical solution, it may be possible to dynamically adjust the regularization in a manner similar to cross validation.
label: concur

sentence: At each step, for the submatrix, one could randomly sample a portion of the entries for ME, while keeping another fraction of the remaining entries as a validation set.
label: concur

sentence: If the recovered matrix via ME has a low reconstruction error on the validation set, it is likely that a suitable low-rank approximation is sufficient and has been found by the ME oracle.
label: concur

sentence: In contrast, if the reconstruction error is large, the algorithm might have been too aggressive on finding a low-rank solution while a higher rank solution is indeed necessary.
label: concur

sentence: As such, one could then adjust the algorithm to increase the number of observations for ME or try to reduce the level of low-rank regularization.
label: concur

sentence: The above cross validation scheme might be an interesting complement to our current approach.
label: concur

sentence: Overall, we believe that principally solving those questions you posted are meaningful and important directions that worth further investigations.
label: concur

sentence: 3). Beyond the low-rank assumption and use a more elaborate type of prior:
label: nonarg

sentence: Thank you for your inspiring advice.
label: nonarg

sentence: Without any elaborate prior information, rank is a natural point to study the global property of a matrix.
label: concur

sentence: In principle, understanding structures in MDP could also be potentially explored, and we believe that it is possible to extend to other types of scenarios with prior information about the MDPs.
label: concur

sentence: However, at the current stage, we do not have a particularly systematic approach to explore more elaborate type of structures in MDPs.
label: concur

sentence: While this paper is focusing on low-rank structures, as the reviewer noted, there can be other structures to be explored.
label: concur

sentence: We hope that our paper could serve as an example, and further motivates future studies for exploiting structures in MDP.
label: concur

sentence: 4). Notation in Section 4.2:
label: nonarg

sentence: Thank you for the suggestion.
label: nonarg

sentence: We will expand the definition of the notation to make them clearer.
label: concur

sentence: Thank you for the comments!
label: nonarg

As long as the state inputs for the discriminator are the same, then MI discriminator can be transferred among different tasks.

sentence: We thank the reviewer for his comments and observations.
label: nonarg

sentence: Following are the answers to each question you have raised.
label: nonarg

sentence: R1Q1(a): “The classification of base class into super classes seems questionable to me.
label: nonarg

sentence: In the meta-learning language, the author attempts to learn a good representation of graphs
label: nonarg

sentence: based on different graph classification tasks generated by a task distribution
label: nonarg

sentence: In terms of graph classification, the task distribution is supported on the joint distributions (G, Y).”
label: nonarg

sentence: R1A1(a): Our model has two major components, $C^{sup}$ (for super-class prediction) and $C^{GAT}$ (for graph label prediction).
label: concur

sentence: During the training phase of our classification, $C^{sup}$, which is a MLP layer, learns the super-class labels of the samples based on GIN’s extracted feature vectors (which represent base class labeled graphs).
label: concur

sentence: While, $C^{GAT}$ takes as input the “graph of graphs” (supergraph) which models the latent inter-class as well as intra-class information and is constructed in every training batch, along with base-class labels, to learn the associated class distribution.
label: concur

sentence: Then, during the fine-tuning phase on graphs with novel class labels, the feature extractor’s (GIN) parameters are fixed and $C^{sup}$ is used to infer the super-class label of the novel class labeled graphs.
label: concur

sentence: Then, the parameters learned by $C^{GAT}$ get updated and further “fine-tuned” for better performance on the novel samples.
label: concur

sentence: In addition to our brief overview, you could also find a very neatly detailed summarization of our method in reviewer 2’s comments (paragraphs 1-4).
label: nonarg

sentence: The meta-learning framework, where batches are sampled as “episodes” with N-way K-shot setting, does not perform as well in our few-shot setting on graphs for the following reasons:
label: concur

sentence: 1) We have very limited total number of training classes (in order of 10s), when compared to the image domain (order of 100s and 1000s).
label: concur

sentence: This limitation hampers learning across tasks and generalization to new unseen tasks.
label: concur

sentence: 2) In each of our batches, we randomly sample a fixed-size of training samples belonging to the set of N labels chosen.
label: concur

sentence: Therefore, when building our supergraph, we end up with k-NN graphs of “variable size” per super-class, compared to fixed size (K nodes) k-NN graphs that we would have got using episodic learning.
label: concur

sentence: We suspect this further allows our GAT to learn and generalize better to unseen graphs.
label: concur

sentence: Furthermore, in [1], the authors use a similar strategy in their “baseline++” method and produce good results.
label: concur

sentence: Their findings are also in sync with our empirical finding.
label: concur

sentence: [1] Chen et~al. “A closer look at Few-Shot Classification”, ICLR 2019
label: nonarg

sentence: R1Q1(b): Hence, to characterize different tasks, as far as I am concerned, the classification should take both the graph G and the label Y into consideration, instead of solely the graph.”
label: nonarg

sentence: R1A1(b): In every batch of graphs during both training and fine-tuning phase, each graph is associated with its corresponding graph label.
label: dispute

sentence: In case of training, its a base-class and in the case of fine-tuning its a novel class
label: dispute

sentence: In the case of $C^{GAT}$, the graph is accompanied by a regular class label and in case of $C^{sup}$, the graph is accompanied by a superclass label.
label: dispute

sentence: R1Q2: “Though seemingly very important to the architecture, the purpose of constructing the super-graph $g^{sup}$ in the training of $C^{CAT}$ seems to be unclear to me.”
label: nonarg

sentence: R1A2: What makes few-shot learning particularly difficult compared to common machine learning settings is the dearth of training examples, which results in a bad empirical risk approximation for the expected risk and therefore gives rise to an empirical risk minimizer that is sub-optimal.
label: concur

sentence: Reducing the required sample complexity can result in a better empirical risk minimizer.
label: concur

sentence: Therefore, given a very large space of hypotheses H, our goal is to further restrict and constrain H using some prior knowledge because a reduced H has reduced sample complexity and thus requires fewer training samples to be trained.
label: concur

sentence: We provide this “prior knowledge” in the form of a “graph of graphs”, namely our super-graph $g^{sup}$, which captures both the latent inter-class and intra-class relationships between classes.
label: concur

sentence: Observe that in $g^{sup}$, we build a k-NN graph PER super-class, restricting any flow of information between super-classes, thus further restricting H. We force our model to jointly learn both the superclass and graph class labels.
label: concur

sentence: This way similar classes (grouped under a superclass) together contribute to learning a general prior representing the superclasses and each superclass also provides “guidance” to better train with the few samples assigned to that superclass.
label: concur

sentence: The introduction of this prior knowledge in the form of a supergraph in $C^{GAT}$ during training also helps generalize better to the novel samples that are presented to our model in the fine-tuning stage.
label: concur

sentence: Additionally, we would also like to draw attention to the supergraph usage summary provided by reviewer 2 in paragraph 3 of their comments.
label: nonarg

sentence: We thank the reviewer for their time and welcome feedback, which we are incorporating into the revised version.
label: nonarg

sentence: R: - "important features for the new task should be in similar locations ..."
label: nonarg

sentence: - "the locations for important features should be comparatively stable ..."
label: nonarg

sentence: A:
label: nonarg

sentence: -- Continual learning typically assumes a degree of similarity among the tasks.
label: dispute

sentence: If tasks are completely different from each other, then most continual learning frameworks will somehow struggle.
label: dispute

sentence: For example, the standard Split MNIST benchmark is in line with this “locations of important features” assumption.
label: dispute

sentence: Having said that, we acknowledge that more agility to, at least, discover that early on would be beneficial.
label: concur

sentence: More importantly, a normalization strategy on top of our attention map would help enhance its invariance properties, potentially leading to a more robust treatment of the locations of important features.
label: concur

sentence: In page 4 in the revised version (footnote 3), we have clarified this and notified its potential for future work.
label: concur

sentence: -- Thank you for the suggestion regarding the fixed attention map.
label: concur

sentence: We tried an experiment using the fixed attention map as a baseline, and as expected it performs significantly worse than ours.
label: concur

sentence: We have added that to the revised version (see p.6 and Appendix A).
label: concur

sentence: R: - FSM vs. Classification performance
label: nonarg

sentence: A:
label: nonarg

sentence: -- It is true that evaluating the FSM is not necessarily the same as the classification results, which is precisely the reason why we show both in our results.
label: dispute

sentence: As specified in page 2, “Here we propose a new measure ...” - our point in this regard is to propose another (different) manner via which catastrophic forgetting can be estimated, which is not the same as the classification accuracy.
label: nonarg

sentence: The goal is that (as we know and agree they are two different measures that might agree or disagree in their judgments on catastrophic forgetting) both can be used to inspect the degree of catastrophic forgetting.
label: nonarg

sentence: We have further clarified that in Section 6.2 in the experiments by stressing that the obtained FSM results “along with the classification results” denote the significance of the whole framework in addressing catastrophic forgetting.
label: nonarg

sentence: It is definitely a good idea to analyse the correlation between changes in classification accuracy and in FSM values, thank you. We will rigorously investigate this in future work.
label: concur

sentence: R: - Statistical significance
label: nonarg

sentence: A:
label: nonarg

sentence: -- Thank you.
label: concur

sentence: We have added the statistical significance results to the revised version.
label: concur

sentence: Since we were concerned that adding this information to the plots would make them harder to read
label: concur

sentence: ,  statistical significance of the the average accuracy and FSM results obtained after completing the last two tasks from each dataset, i.e. the corresponding values of the last two tasks of all the plots in Figures 1, 2, 3 and 4, are now displayed in the tables in Appendix A.
label: concur

sentence: Checking cases where the learner incorrectly classifies the image in the second time step is sound and will be inspected in future work.
label: concur

sentence: R: - Clarity
label: nonarg

sentence: A:
label: nonarg

sentence: -- We have fixed the typos in the revised version, thank you: i) The first sentence of the third paragraph in Section 4 now reads: “For input images of ..., the averaged weight of evidence matrix  is referred to as $\text{WE}_{\bm{i}}(\bm{x}) \in \RR^{\bm{r} \times \bm{c}}$.”  ii) In page 6: “The size of the surrounding square … is 16 $\times$ 16 pixels.
label: concur

sentence: We thank our third reviewer for his comment.
label: nonarg

sentence: We do understand your concern about the significant increase in computational time.
label: concur

sentence: However, we believe that in the context of active learning, the main problem is not related to computational power, rather to the scarcity of data.
label: dispute

sentence: Therefore, a better way of making the most out of little data is critical.
label: dispute

sentence: For example, a 10 \% increase for only 300 samples acquired, could make a huge difference in a critical field where active learning is most valuable.
label: dispute

sentence: We believe that this is exactly what we manage to achieve with our method and this comes as a result of a better representation of uncertainty during AL.
label: dispute

sentence: Furthermore,  Beluch et al. (2018) showed that going beyond 3 networks in their deterministic ensemble method does not add any significant improvements in terms of performance.
label: concur

sentence: Therefore we use 3 stochastic ensembles for our method.

sentence: Thank you for your thorough assessment and helpful comments! To answer your two questions:
label: nonarg

sentence: 1) Upper bound
label: nonarg

sentence: You are right that it would be ideal to optimize the target loss L_T(h, f_T) directly.
label: dispute

sentence: However, this is not possible because we do not have labelled target data (i.e., f_T is unknown).
label: dispute

sentence: Minimizing an upper bound is arguably the only viable option *with theoretical generalization guarantee*. It is a common practice in the domain adaptation community (Mansour et al., 2009a, 2009b; Ben-David et al. 2007, 2010; Cortes and Mohri, 2011), and it is essentially the key idea of PAC learning and generalization analysis (Györfi et al., 2006; Schölkopf et al., 2002; Vapnik, 2013).
label: dispute

sentence: Besides, our method *directly* optimizes the upper bound without resorting to heuristics, unlike prior methods.
label: dispute

sentence: Remark 2. Expression, and details (ex. number of iterations, stopping criteria, typos and grammar errors)
label: nonarg

sentence: A : We apologize to the reviewer for the lack of clarity in the manuscript.
label: concur

sentence: We have modified our expression, typos and grammar errors.
label: concur

sentence: Regarding the details on hyper-parameters:
label: concur

sentence: - We set parameters as follows.
label: concur

sentence: The number of training iteration and thresholding epsilon are very important parameters in our algorithm and have a considerable correlation with each other.
label: concur

sentence: In the first experiment, the iteration number remains fixed and the growth rate of epsilon is adjusted so that the validation accuracy saturates near the settled iteration number.
label: concur

sentence: While the validation accuracy is evaluated using the cross-validation, we set the number of training iteration to be 100 so that the model is trained enough until it saturates.
label: concur

sentence: Epsilon is increased in log-scale and begins at a very small value (10^(−5)) where no data is added.
label: concur

sentence: The growth rate of epsilon is determined according to when the validation accuracy saturates.
label: concur

sentence: The stopping criterion is that the accuracy of the current iteration reaches the average accuracy of the previous 20 steps.
label: concur

sentence: If the stopping iteration is much less than 100 times, the epsilon growth rate should be reduced so that the data is added more slowly.
label: concur

sentence: If the stopping iteration significantly exceeds 100 iterations, the epsilon growth rate should be increased so that the data is added more easily.
label: concur

sentence: We allow 5 iterations as a deviation from 100 iterations and the growth rate of epsilon is left unchanged in this interval.
label: concur

sentence: (In previous versions, the growth ratio of epsilon for CIFAR-10 was applied to SVHN and CIFAR-100.
label: concur

sentence: However, since the epsilon growth rate is different for each dataset, as the reviewer mentioned, we have performed the cross-validation for SVHN and CIFAR-100 and modified our results.) As a result, the epsilon is gradually increased in log-scale by 10 times every 33 iterations in CIFAR-10 and SVHN.
label: concur

sentence: In the case of CIFAR-100, the epsilon is increased by 10 times in log-scale every 27 iterations.
label: concur

sentence: In the second experiment, we leave the epsilon fixed and simply train the model until the stopping criterion is satisfied.
label: concur

sentence: Other details are the same as those of the first experiment.
label: concur

sentence: (In previous versions, the training iterations of fixed mode had been fixed.
label: concur

sentence: Thanks to the comment from the reviewer, we were able to rearrange the content and set training iteration by cross-validation.)
label: concur

sentence: We acknowledge that the time complexity of our pre-training methods was not well explained in Appendix F. In Figure 2 (a) we show that we only sample one node per graph.
label: concur

sentence: We then use breadth-first search to extract a K-hop neighborhood of the node, which takes at most linear time with respect to the number of edges in the graph.

sentence: As a result, pre-training via context prediction has linear time complexity.

sentence: "The purpose of generative models is not to interpolate per se; the interpolation is really a sanity check that the model is capturing the underlying distribution rather than just memorizing training examples.
label: nonarg

sentence: The function composition doesn't capture that.
label: nonarg

sentence: I think the authors should just acknowledge that you can't soundly *sample* from their generative model the way e.g. VAE or GAN allows (their function composition is not a sampling method).
label: nonarg

sentence: But I think there are lots of useful things you can do without that capability, e.g. do 3D point cloud completion, go image -> structure, etc. I think this function composition angle should be deemphasized in the title/abstract, but I think the paper stands  reasonably on its own without that."
label: nonarg

sentence: We agree that the current formulation of composition is not equivalent to a generative model.
label: concur

sentence: In our work, function composition primarily serves the purpose of demonstrating that the model learns a meaningful subspace of objects (rather than memorizing the training set, as you mentioned).
label: dispute

sentence: We have revised the abstract to clarify this point.
label: concur

sentence: "In Figure 2 it's pretty hard to see the differences between the methods. What exactly is being visualized here? DeepSDF shold be visualizing surface normals vs. HOF which is point clouds, right?"
label: nonarg

sentence: We have clarified in the manuscript that our comparisons are between architectures, rather than training objectives/output representations.
label: concur

sentence: Thus our DeepSDF, FoldingNet, and HOF architectures all output point clouds, which can be compared directly.
label: concur

sentence: "For predicting a deformation R^3 -> R^3 function composition sort of makes sense, but how generalizable is this approach e.g. to directly predicting a function R^3 -> R (a la DeepSDF)? I think there are ways this function composition approach could generalize, e.g. using skip connections and layer dropout (which encourages layers to be composable)."
label: nonarg

sentence: Additional techniques for promoting learning of composable representations such as skip connections and layer dropout are an exciting direction for future research.
label: concur

sentence: One way function composition might allow for R^3 -> R mappings by composing a mapping from R^3 -> R^3 and taking the only first dimension of each element in the final output.
label: concur

sentence: Concern 1: Concerns with title “Meta Domain Adaptation”
label: nonarg

sentence: “…unlike as advertised, the paper does not address
label: nonarg

sentence: It appears that our choice of the title may have resulted in the reviewer qualifying our paper as a form of false advertising.
label: concur

sentence: We acknowledge this problem and agree with you about a possible misinterpretation.
label: concur

sentence: However, we feel this maybe a bit harsh, as in the technical content of the paper (Abstract, Introduction, etc.), we have been very clear about the motivation and the problem setting, and do not think we did any form of false advertising.
label: dispute

sentence: We also do think that the problem setting we have proposed is an important problem that deserves attention, and has not been studied in the meta-learning paradigm.
label: dispute

sentence: We are glad that you also agree that setting makes sense (“... the combination … is fair”).
label: dispute

sentence: Overall, we think that we have made an important contribution to Meta-Learning literature, by identifying its limitation for few-shot learning under domain shift, and proposed a solution to tackle this problem.
label: dispute

sentence: We have tried to revise the draft with appropriate renaming of the method to avoid potential misunderstandings.
label: concur

sentence: In fact, we have mostly changed the name from “Meta Domain Adaptation” to “Meta Learning with Domain Adaptation”, and the rest of the paper is almost identical, which we believe addresses the concerns of false advertising.
label: concur

sentence: Concern 2: Experiments
label: nonarg

sentence: Domain Adaptation Baselines + Other datasets
label: nonarg

sentence: Being a new problem setting, designing appropriate baselines can be challenging.
label: dispute

sentence: We considered the traditional meta-learning for few-shot learning approaches, and combined meta-learning with a popular domain adaptation baseline.
label: concur

sentence: It is something we should have done on our own.
label: concur

sentence: Accordingly, based on your suggestions, and suggestions from other reviewers, we have tried to expand the baselines substantially (specifically, we include three state of the art Domain Adaptation methods as baselines – RevGrad [1], ADDA [2] and CyCADA [3]), and our proposed methods outperform them.
label: concur

sentence: For the other dataset suggested (VisDA), for synthetic-real adaptation, it is difficult to match the training paradigm of meta-learning.
label: dispute

sentence: Typically, we desire several classes for meta-train, and several classes for meta-test, so that a variety of (e.g.) 5-way tasks can be crawn.
label: dispute

sentence: With just 12 classes, the dataset is not very suitable for such settings.
label: dispute

sentence: We appreciate the concern in the updated comments, but would like to point out that the novelty in our work should be viewed from two angles: the need to study this problem (i.e., the problem setting), and the proposed solution.
label: dispute

sentence: We have identified a novel problem setting, which is closer to the real world setting, than what has been studied so far under the meta-learning paradigm.
label: dispute

sentence: Existing solutions are not effective in this setting, restricting their use in the real world.
label: dispute

sentence: Addressing this setting in our framework gives us a direction to improve the practical utility of meta-learning solutions for few-shot learning.
label: dispute

sentence: Specifically, we identify that the principle of image-to-image translation is very suitable for this setting, and apply those concepts to boost the performance of few-shot learning under domain shift.
label: dispute

sentence: As a combination of problem setting and proposed solution, we do believe we have addressed an important problem, and made a novel contribution.
label: dispute

sentence: As regards the experiments: “fairly small datasets

sentence: … feature extractor backbone”
label: nonarg

sentence: Most domain adaptation experiments use MNIST, USPS, SVHN, which are comparable in size to our Omniglot experiments.
label: dispute

sentence: The other popular benchmark is using the Office-dataset, which also we have used (although a more recent version of a similar dataset, i.e., office-home – more suitable for meta-learning evaluation, as it has larger number of classes).
label: dispute

sentence: See for example some of the recent domain adaptation papers [1, 2, 3].
label: nonarg

sentence: While a feature extractor backbone network may have some influence, we would like to highlight three points.
label: nonarg

sentence: First, when networks are trained in one domain, and evaluated in another, regardless of the backbone network, it is the domain-shift that dominates the performance.
label: concur

sentence: For example, no matter how large the network is, if it is trained to recognize black and white digits, it will still struggle to recognize colored digits.
label: concur

sentence: Second, any benefit of a larger backbone network will likely also enhance the performance of our model.
label: concur

sentence: Third, we just wanted to clarify (if there was a misunderstanding), unlike domain adaptation papers, we do not use a pretrained network – we train the full network from scratch (following traditional meta-training settings).

label: nonarg

label: nonarg

sentence: We will make revisions to address the several points you have raised in your review.
label: nonarg

sentence: Below we first address the main concerns.
label: nonarg

sentence: Q1: “Alt-az” rotation is not a group.
label: concur

sentence: A1: Thank you for pointing this out.
label: concur

sentence: You are correct.
label: concur

sentence: The Alt-az rotation, according to our definition, is not a group.
label: concur

sentence: SO(3)  is a group which can be parametrized by a 3-sphere .
label: concur

sentence: But when we reduce one parameter from it, it is not a group anymore mathematically; the composition of two alt-az rotations becomes a general rotation in SO(3).
label: concur

sentence: In the new revision, we will use the term alt-az rotation in “quotient SO(3)/SO(2)”  instead of alt-az rotation group.
label: concur

sentence: Moreover, the quotient SO(3)/SO(2) is isomorphic to $S^2$ and to avoid the ill-definition on the two poles (the two degenerate points), we will add a constraint to the alt-az rotation, i.e. $\phi=0, if \theta=0 or \theta=\pi$. This is because, when the altitude rotation is zero or PI, the azimuth rotation is meaningless in a alt-az rotation and is therefore fixed as zero.
label: dispute

sentence: If $\theta=0 or \theta=pi, and “\phi \neq 0$, this rotation belongs to the azimuthal rotation in SO(2) group.
label: dispute

sentence: (Q2) Equivariance property of the Alt-az convolution
label: concur

sentence: We think we can still have the equivariance property but only for single alt-az rotation.
label: dispute

sentence: Notice the definition of alt-az convolution do not use any composite rotation.
label: dispute

sentence: Here is our tentative proof:
label: dispute

sentence: Under the definition of alt-azimuth anisotropic convolution and using the unitary property (5) of rotation operators, we have (assume the number of channels K=1 for simplicity, assume Q and R be both alt-az rotations):
label: dispute

sentence: \begin{equation}
label: dispute

sentence: \begin{aligned}
label: dispute

sentence: & (h \star D_{Q} f) (R)
label: dispute

sentence: = \int_{S^2}(D_Rh)(\hat{u})f(Q^{-1}\hat{u})ds(\hat{u}) \\
label: dispute

sentence: =\int_{S^2}h(R^{-1}Q\hat{u})f(\hat{u})ds(\hat{u}) \\
label: dispute

sentence: =(h \star f)(Q^{-1}R) = D_{Q}( h \star f)(R)
label: dispute

sentence: \end{aligned}
label: dispute

sentence: \end{equation}
label: dispute

sentence: This means that for a single alt-az rotation of input spherical image; the output of a convolution layer will rotate in the same way.
label: dispute

sentence: Although the property doesn’t hold if one performs multiple alt-az rotations to the input spherical image, it is still valuable because we assume the different SO(3) orientation of an input 3D shape is from a composite of an azimuthal rotation and an alt-az rotation, the azimuthal rotation is treated by data augmentation and the single alt-az rotation is treated by the network equivariance and invariance.
label: dispute

sentence: Q3: alt-az convolution is not well defined on the south pole
label: concur

sentence: A3: Yes, we agree that our original definition of alt-az convolution is not well defined on both north and south poles.
label: concur

sentence: Therefore, in the new revision, we will add the constraints to the definition of alt-az rotation and make it one-to-one corresponds to the set points on $S^2$. See A1.
label: concur

sentence: Q4: The paragraph motivating the alt-az convolution on page 4 is not very clear.
label: concur

sentence: A4: Thanks for the comments, as you suggested, we will rewrite this paragraph in the new version, and acknowledge the importance and effectiveness of the recent work on the group equivariance and rotation invariant networks.
label: concur

sentence: Q5: It would be nice to see a more direct comparison between the three definitions of spherical convolution (general SO3, isotropic S2, and anisotropic S2)
label: concur

sentence: A5: The two related papers (Cohen et al 2018 for general SO3 and Esteves, and Esteves et al 2018 for isotropic S2) both use lat-lon grid and Fourier domain convolution, while ours uses a icosahedron-sphere grid and direct spherical domain convolution.
label: concur

sentence: The use of different sampling in the input spherical image, and the use of filters are totally different.
label: concur

sentence: We think a direct comparison should be done in one of the following ways : (a) perform the three types of spherical convolution all using icosahedron-sphere grid and then convolve in the spherical domain.
label: concur

sentence: (b) perform the three types of spherical convolution all using lat-lon grid and convolve in the Fourier domain.
label: concur

sentence: For the first type of direct comparison, to implement isotropic spherical convolution (Type II), we should make the geodesic disc filter share an identical weight along the angular direction.
label: concur

sentence: To implement a general SO(3) spherical convolution, we should add a rotation degree of freedom into our disc filter.
label: concur

sentence: We are conducting this experiment and if the time and paper page limit are allowed, we will report the comparison result in the revised version.
label: concur

sentence: Otherwise, we will put it into our future work.
label: concur

sentence: For the second type of direct comparison, we need to conduct alt-az spherical convolution in the Fourier domain, this is possible by determining the spherical harmonic coefficient, $<g_0, Y_l^m> $ for the alt-az convolution in terms of the spherical harmonic coefficient of input spherical signal $f$ and the filter $h$. This comparison needs re-designing of our network and we can not finish it within the rebuttal period, we’ll leave it for future work.
label: concur

sentence: Q6: Initially, I was a bit puzzled about why SO(3) augmentation seems to reduce accuracy in table 1.
label: concur

sentence: I think this is because SO(3) augmentation actually makes the classification problem harder if the input is initially aligned.
label: concur

sentence: Some more explanation / discussion would be good.
label: concur

sentence: A6: Theoretically, our method will be rotation invariant with only AZ rotation, it will be full rotation invariant with SO(2) rotation augmentation about an arbitrary axis .
label: concur

sentence: In table I, we believe the reason alt-az augmentation performs better because it contains more training data.
label: concur

sentence: SO(3) augmentation underperforms the AZ augmentation because several random SO(3) rotation augmentation might not be able to cover all the relative rotation wrt the filter's orientation (see appendix).
label: concur

sentence: Q7: It would be nice to explain the spherical parameterization in more detail.
label: concur

sentence: Is this operation itself rotation equivariant?
label: concur

sentence: A7: Due to the page limit of the conference paper, we could not explain the spherical parameterization method in detail.
label: concur

sentence: This operation is theoretically rotation equivariant.
label: concur

sentence: Spherical parameterization establishes a map that transforms the points of a closed surface into the points on the unit sphere.
label: concur

sentence: A good spherical mapping for a closed surface should satisfy the following properties:bijective mapping and least distortion.
label: concur

sentence: Bijective mapping is the most important but most difficult in this process which implies that the resulting map is one-to-one, fold-free, and therefore feature preserving (information lossless).
label: concur

sentence: Least distortion seeks a good sampling rate such that interesting features of the model receive enough real estate on the sphere in order to be accurately sampled.
label: concur

sentence: We achieved the bijective mapping by adapting a coarse-to-fine strategy with minor modifications (See http://hhoppe.com/proj/sphereparam/).
label: concur

sentence: The minimizing of the map distortion is obtained using the authalic parameterization proposed in Sinha et al 2016.
label: concur

sentence: This process is rotation equivariant because the initial bijective mapping is depends on the object orientation and the authalic remeshing does not change the orientation of the spherical embeddings.
label: concur

sentence: Spherical parameterization is a good way to retain geometric and topological information of original shapes (compared to the spherical projection method), but currently it works only for genus-0 closed object, extending it to 3d shapes with arbitrary topology is still an unsolved problem, that is why we could not adapt this method for dataset such as ModelNET and Shrec’17, they contain 3D objects with arbitrary topology.
label: concur

sentence: (Q8) Other typos and minor issues
label: concur

sentence: We will correct all the typos and other minor issues in the revised paper, thank you again for the detailed review. WE really appreciate your help.
label: concur

sentence: Thank you for pointing out the other datasets in algebraic word reasoning.
label: nonarg

sentence: We’ve included these in an expanded discussion of related work with discussion on how they relate to the current dataset.
label: concur

sentence: Please let us know if we have missed other papers.
label: nonarg

sentence: Your proposal of combining multiple extant problem sets is a good idea.
label: nonarg

sentence: We’d want to ensure the combined datasets have a common format (e.g., the same unambiguous freeform text format for reasons of transferability, etc as argued in the paper), and there are interesting problem types occurring in other datasets (such as logical entailment or boolean satisfiability) that we haven’t yet included.
label: dispute

sentence: We may in the future extend the dataset to include these other problem types if the current ones become solved, and of course we solicit contributions (in the form of generation code) to the dataset.
label: concur

sentence: We likely could not use workbooks etc as a source for problems without significant investment, since obtaining legal permission to redistribute copyrighted problems found in these books would probably be hard and/or expensive.
label: dispute

sentence: Having said that, it is definitely important to ensure the problems remain grounded in real-life problems (thus our small list of real-life exam questions).
label: dispute

sentence: This was the motivation for testing trained models against “real life” questions occurring in school-level examinations; these questions are not intended to be a primary benchmark (with more questions and detailed grades), but rather simply a rough indication of whether training models to answer school-level questions could be achievable.
label: dispute

sentence: On the distribution of the sampled answer (and the related question of how difficulty levels are determined), these are great questions.
label: nonarg

sentence: For some modules with two output choices (e.g., True, False), we can simply split the answers 50-50.
label: concur

sentence: But in general, the answer distribution depends on the module, with hand-tuning to ensure the (question, answer) pair is of a reasonable difficulty level as judged by humans.
label: concur

sentence: In more detail: as mentioned in the paper, we want to achieve upper bounds on the maximum probability that any single (question, answer) is sampled; thus if we sample the answer from a set of N possible answers, then to achieve a maximum probability p of a given question, the remaining choices made in generating the question must
label: concur

sentence: be from a set of size p/N. We roughly aim to pick N (depending on p) so that conditioned on this, the question is as easy as possible; there is typically a hand-tuned sweet spot.
label: concur

sentence: On evaluating general-purpose models only, we may have phrased this badly in the paper, and have updated it.
label: concur

sentence: We are definitely interested in any models that learns to do mathematics and symbolic reasoning, which would include more sophisticated models tailored towards doing mathematics (one could imagine models with working memory, etc).
label: concur

sentence: However, we discount models that already have their mathematics knowledge inbuilt rather than learnt (for example, this includes many of the models that occur in algebraic reasoning tasks, where the model learns to map the input text to an existing equation template, that is then solved by a fixed calculator).
label: concur

sentence: We test DNC (differentiable neural computers) and RMC (relational memory core) models, which arguably are more specialized for doing mathematics, since they have a slot-based memory that may be appropriate for storing intermediate results.
label: concur

sentence: However these models obtained worse performance than the more general architectures, and we are not yet aware of models that are more tailored for doing mathematics that do not simply have their mathematics knowledge built-in and unlearnable; we hope the dataset will spur the development of new models along these lines.
label: concur

sentence: On the number of thinking steps, in our earlier analysis we trained up to 150k steps (compared with 500k for final performance reported in paper), and observed the following interpolation test performances by number of steps: 39% (0 steps), 46% (1 step), 48% (2), 49% (4), 50% (8), 51% (16).
label: concur

sentence: We are re-running experiments now to confirm the final performances, which we can include in the final paper.
label: concur

sentence: We thank the reviewer for acknowledging the novelty of our work and for noting that our experiments are thorough.
label: nonarg

sentence: Thank you for pointing out a related preprint by Z. Hu et al. [arXiv:1905.13728].
label: nonarg

sentence: We note the work by Z. Hu et al. was developed independently and concurrently to our work here, and we were not aware of it at the time of writing our paper.
label: concur

sentence: We shall cite the preprint and include a discussion in our paper.
label: concur

sentence: Briefly, the key difference between our work and that of Hu et al. is that Hu et al. consider a more restrictive setting where graphs are completely unlabeled (i.e., graphs have no node features).
label: concur

sentence: Hu et al. then focus on extracting generic graph properties of unlabeled graphs by pre-training on randomly-generated graphs.
label: concur

sentence: While the approach is interesting, the limitation of such an approach is that it improves performance only marginally over ordinary supervised classification of the original attributed graphs.
label: concur

sentence: This is because it is hard for random unlabeled graphs to capture domain-specific knowledge that is useful for a specific application.
label: concur

sentence: Moreover, in practice, graphs tend to have labels together with rich node and edge attributes, but Hu et al.’s approach cannot naturally leverage such attribute information, which then results in limited gains.
label: concur

sentence: In principle, we could compare our approach against Hu et al., however, right now, this would be extremely challenging because of the following reasons.
label: concur

sentence: (1) We cannot find a public implementation of Hu et al.’s approach for reliable comparison.
label: concur

sentence: (2) Reimplementing their method requires knowledge of many specific implementational details and design choices (feature extraction, graph generation, etc.), which are not discussed in their preprint.
label: concur

sentence: (3) Finally, their pre-trained GNN operates on unlabeled graphs, and so it cannot be directly applied to our datasets of labeled graphs.
label: concur

sentence: Lastly, in contrast to Hu et al., our work focuses on important real-world domains, where one wants to pre-train GNNs by utilizing the abundant graph, node, and edge attributes.
label: concur

sentence: Importantly, our approach is able to learn a domain-specific data distribution that is useful for downstream prediction.
label: concur

sentence: We demonstrate on two application domains that such practical settings (i.e., labeled graphs with naturally-given node and edge attributes) are very important to consider and that our pre-training can substantially improve model performance.
label: concur

sentence: We thank Reviewer 3 (R3) for their review and for clearly articulating their concerns regarding the paper.
label: nonarg

sentence: In our response below, we will clarify the design and results of our experiments as well as argue why we believe that these results should be of interest and are not, indeed, that predictable.
label: nonarg

sentence: R3 asked why training performance of many models is 100% when they do not generalize and suggested us to perform a large number of training runs to see if occasionally the right solution is found.
label: nonarg

sentence: First, we agree that from the point of view of training there are many equally good solutions, and in fact, this is the main and the only challenge of SQOOP.
label: concur

sentence: We designed the task with the goal of testing which models are more likely to converge to the right solution, with which they can handle all possible combinations of objects, despite being trained only on a small subset of objects.
label: concur

sentence: We argued extensively in the introduction that such an ability to find the systematic solution despite other alternatives being available is highly desirable for language understanding approaches.
label: concur

sentence: We fully agree with R3 that in investigations of whether or not a particular model converges to the right solution repeating every experiment several times is absolutely necessary, and we would like to emphasize that we did repeat each experiment 3, 5, or 10 times (see “details” in Table 1 and the paragraph “Parametrization Induction” on page 8).
label: concur

sentence: In most cases we saw a consistent success or consistent failure, one exception being the parametrization induction results, where 4 out of 10 runs were successful (see Table 4, row 1 for the mean and the confidence interval).
label: concur

sentence: We hope that 3 takes this fact into account, and we will furthermore improve on the current level of rigor in the upcoming revision by repeating each experiment at least 5 times.
label: concur

sentence: We are not sure if we fully understand the question “Could you somehow test for if a given trained model will show systematic generalization?” that R3 asked.
label: nonarg

sentence: We test the systematic generalization of a model by evaluating it on all SQOOP questions that were not present in the training set.
label: concur

sentence: We hope that this answers the question of R3 and we would be happy to engage in a further discussion regarding this and make edits to the paper if necessary.
label: nonarg

sentence: We thank R3 for the suggestion to investigate the influence of model size and regularization on systematic generalization.
label: nonarg

sentence: It is indeed a very appropriate question in the  context of our study, however, we note that there exists a wide variety of regularization methods and trying them all (and all their combinations) would be infeasible.
label: dispute

sentence: In the upcoming update of the paper we will report results of an on-going ablation study for the MAC model, in which we vary the module size, the number of modules and experiment with weight decay.
label: concur

sentence: We would welcome any other specific experiment requests R3 may have.
label: nonarg

sentence: Finally, we would like to discuss the significance of our investigation and its results.
label: nonarg

sentence: While we agree that the results that we report may not shock the reader (although perhaps hindsight bias plays a role in what people find surprising or not after reading an article) we find them highly interesting and not at all easily predictable.
label: dispute

sentence: Reading prior work on visual reasoning may lead a researcher to conclude, roughly speaking, that NMNs are a lost cause, since a variety of generic models perform comparably or better.
label: dispute

sentence: In contrast, our rigorous investigation highlights their strong generalization capabilities and relates them to the specific design of NMNs.
label: dispute

sentence: Notably, chain-structured NMNs were used in the literature prior to this work (e.g. in the model of Jonshon et al multiple filter_...[...] modules are often chained), so the fact that tree-structured NMNs show much stronger generalization was not obvious prior to this investigation and should be of a high interest to the research community.
label: dispute

sentence: Last but not least, an important part of our investigation (which the review does not discuss) is the systematic generalization analysis of popular end-to-end NMN versions, that shows how making NMNs more end-to-end makes them more susceptible to finding spurious solutions.
label: dispute

sentence: As we argued in our conclusion, these findings should be of a highest importance to researchers working on end-to-end NMNs, which is a very popular research direction nowadays.
label: dispute

sentence: We conclude our response by announcing that an updated version of the paper, that among others incorporates valuable suggestions by R3, will soon be uploaded to OpenReview.
label: concur

sentence: We are currently performing a lot of additional experiments, the results of which will make our investigation even more rigorous and complete.
label: concur

sentence: We sincerely hope that R3 takes into account the arguments we have made here and the new results that we will publish soon and reevaluates our paper more positively.
label: nonarg

sentence: Dear Reviewer 3,

sentence: We believe both these findings are quite surprising.

sentence: R2: "this 'finishes' [Pathak et al., ICML17] to its logical conclusion for game-based environments and should spur interesting conversations and further research. In terms of actual technical contributions, I believe much less significant."
label: nonarg

sentence: => In the light of the comments on originality and significance, we would like to highlight our finding that random features perform quite well and at times as well as learned features across many environments.
label: dispute

sentence: This is a novel contribution since prior works have relied on learned features as a crucial requirement for good performance [Pathak et. al. ICML17].
label: dispute

sentence: We believe this investigation would allow random features to be seen as an easily reproducible and strong baseline for future investigations of feature learning in exploration.
label: dispute

sentence: Indeed, since the release of our paper, there has been some follow-ups on using random features for exploration in achieving state of the art results on hard exploration games when combined with extrinsic reward (in the interest of preserving anonymity, we don't include the references here).
label: dispute

sentence: R2: "However, it isn't entirely clear if the primary contribution is showing that 'curiosity reward' is a potentially promising approach or if game environments aren't particularly good testbeds for practical RL algorithms"
label: nonarg

sentence: => We believe that both are valuable insofar as generating discussion within the community and leading to follow-up experimentation.
label: dispute

sentence: In particular, we hope our paper stimulates both, an interest in trying out more realistic/stochastic environments, *and* further research on curiosity as a potential useful reward.
label: dispute

sentence: In addition to that, we have shown that curiosity could be a very strong baseline to compare against in future papers.
label: dispute

sentence: All these, we argue, are valuable to the progress and health of the field.
label: dispute

sentence: R2: "Dealing with highly stochastic environments seems a potential fatal flaw of the assumptions of this method. However, as I said previously, this is probably a discussion worth having given the popularity and visibility of game-based testbeds"
label: nonarg

sentence: => We agree that significant amounts of stochasticity would break the method we used in the paper, and it is an important issue to be addressed by future work.
label: concur

sentence: Our vivid demonstration of this issue in the maze environment has already inspired some recent papers to look into, in particular, by incentivizing episodic reachability (in the interest of preserving anonymity, we don't include references to these, but we will include them in the final version of the paper).
label: concur

sentence: R2: "I think that more casual ML/RL researchers will find these results controversial and surprising while more experienced researchers will see curiosity-driven learning to be explainable primarily by the intuition..."

sentence: => Indeed in our experience, although a few people were not surprised, most of them were very surprised at the agents being able to make progress without any any extrinsic rewards.

sentence: This suggests that the game designers (similar to architects, urban planners, gardeners, etc.) are purposefully setting up curricula to guide agents through the task by curiosity alone [Lazzaro, 2004].

sentence: => We will add a discussion of recent works that deal with navigation tasks in maze environments [Mirowski et. al. ICLR 2017, Jaderberg et. al. ICLR 2017] in the related works section.
label: concur

sentence: In contrast to these works, we don't assume privileged access to the maze environment in the form of depth estimation or loop closure supervision.
label: dispute

sentence: Auxiliary tasks are an important component of RL and exploration methods, however, in this work we chose to focus on the most generic setting with minimal assumptions about the environment: providing raw observations in response to actions.
label: dispute

sentence: In environments with privileged access we expect auxiliary tasks to benefit both curiosity-driven and extrinsic-reward-driven RL methods.

sentence: We address the main concerns individually below:
label: nonarg

sentence: Adversarially filtering using BERT and GPT gives deep learning models a disadvantage:
label: nonarg

sentence: While BERT originally achieved high performance on the originally collected dataset, several recent studies [1][2][3][4] have found the presence of annotation artifacts in crowdsourced data that inadvertently leak information about the target label.
label: dispute

sentence: This subsequently leads to overestimation of the performance of AI systems on end tasks.
label: dispute

sentence: Our adversarial filtering (AF) algorithm aims to address the problem of overestimation of performance.
label: dispute

sentence: In spite of targeting GPT/BERT during AF, human performance on the AF resulting dataset is still high.
label: dispute

sentence: The significant gap between human and BERT performance leaves scope for inventing new methods for abductive reasoning.
label: dispute

sentence: Ensemble of BERT models:
label: nonarg

label: concur

sentence: Average score of human:

sentence: This is directly comparable with BERT-Ft [Fully Connected] model’s performance of 68.6% in Table 1.

label: nonarg

label: concur

sentence: To measure human performance, we had three annotators select the correct hypothesis and measured human performance as the accuracy of their majority-vote.

sentence: Generative task vs classification:
label: nonarg

sentence: We completely agree.
label: concur

sentence: While the generative task is more general and much more interesting, the challenge of evaluating generations is significant, particularly for this task.
label: dispute

sentence: This is due to the fact that there could be multiple distinct plausible explanations for a given pair of hypothesis.
label: dispute

sentence: Consider the following example:
label: dispute

sentence: O1: Kelly and her friend wanted to take a train to the city.
label: dispute

sentence: O2: They had to wait for another one.
label: dispute

sentence: Plausible explanations:
label: dispute

sentence: 1. They read the timetable incorrectly and arrived at the station just after a train had left.
label: dispute

sentence: 2. The train was full.
label: dispute

sentence: Both explanations are plausible, and explain the observations, but automated evaluation metrics are not reliable enough to capture this phenomenon based on their reliance on surface level similarities.
label: dispute

sentence: To simultaneously make progress on the novel abductive reasoning task and due to the ease of evaluation, we additionally introduce a discriminative version of the task.
label: dispute

sentence: Nonetheless, we agree that in its most general form, there could be any number of observations and models should be required to generate explanatory hypotheses in natural language (alpha-NLG task).

sentence: @L-BFGS: On a high level, we agree that GGT develops a similar window-based approximation to the gradient Gram matrix as L-BFGS does to the approximated Hessian.

sentence: While adaptive methods have proven effective in practice, quasi-Newton algorithms are not in general regarded as competitive for deep learning (despite recent efforts [1,2]), and that’s why it is not compared to in the vast majority of deep learning papers.
label: concur

sentence: - Quasi-Newton methods are suited for deterministic problems, while stochasticity is crucial in deep learning.
label: concur

sentence: This is because they try to approximate the Hessian by finite differences, which seems unstable with stochastic gradients in practice.
label: concur

sentence: - Direct second-order methods require significant modifications to converge in the non-convex setting (see [3,4]).
label: concur

sentence: Even these have not been observed to work well in deep learning.
label: concur

sentence: - One reason for the practical success of AdaGrad-like algorithms we believe is the difference of  -1/2 vs. -1 power on the Gram matrix, which seems to change the training dynamics dramatically.
label: concur

sentence: With the gradient Gram matrix and a -1 power, meaningful end-to-end advances have only been claimed for niche tasks other than classification.
label: concur

sentence: Regarding theorem 1 and the sample complexity of MINE, we also had discussions on why we think they are comparable or not and discussed that on page 5 in our submission.
label: concur

sentence: The tldr is that the MINE sample complexity can not only be seen as 1) bounding best achievable MI estimation but also as 2) bounding distance from estimation to a proven MI lower bound.
label: concur

sentence: The former is a quite vacuous bound on generalization and would require advances in learning theory to improve, not MI estimation.
label: concur

sentence: Our theorem 1 is trying to improve the latter to enable practical applications.
label: concur

sentence: Improving the former to the level of practical use is a noble goal, let us know when you have an answer.
label: concur

sentence: Regarding "false detection" experiments.
label: nonarg

sentence: We really appreciate that you brought up this point.
label: nonarg

sentence: Our synthetic experiments on Gaussians rho=0.0 in Figure 1 do exactly this.
label: concur

sentence: Results show that MINE-f and MINE-f-ES estimates very much non-zero MI when there should have been 0 MI.
label: concur

sentence: MINE-f bar is not visible due to overshooting out of the chart.
label: concur

sentence: DEMINE approaches give estimations closer to 0.
label: concur

sentence: We often get questions about why our estimators give MI numbers lower than MINE and why are we claiming that our estimator is better.
label: concur

sentence: But in fact that's exactly because MINE gives false detection but our estimators provably don't.
label: concur

sentence: Hyper-parameter search example.
label: nonarg

sentence: Say we are given 3000 paired (x,y) observations.
label: concur

sentence: First divide into 1500 train, 1500 test.
label: concur

sentence: Take 1500 train and run Algorithm 1 using 3-fold crossval: use 1000 for (x,y)train and 500 for (x,y)val in each run (3 runs total).
label: concur

sentence: Get MI estimation m1,m2,m3 over 3 folds.
label: concur

sentence: Compute confidence interval v using Eq.8 using the hyperparameters and 1500 as test set size.
label: concur

sentence: Hyperparameter search DEMINE-vr maximizes mean([m1,m2,m3])-2std([m1,m2,m3]).
label: concur

sentence: DEMINE-sig maximizes mean([m1,m2,m3])-v.
label: concur

sentence: Will try to make it more clear.

sentence: Regarding fMRI experiments, our focus is on demonstrating neural MI estimation and dependency test on fMRI data.

sentence: We compare with pearson's correlation because it's another widely used technique that can perform both correlation analysis as well as significance test.
label: concur

sentence: We used a simple 1D CNN where convolution happens over the time dimension, not the spatial dimensions.
label: concur

sentence: Better architectures, e.g. transformers over time + graph networks over space could improve performance, but not our focus and we leave that to future work.

sentence: Higher-order and nonlinear covariance tests may make very appealing comparisons and we are looking into it.
label: concur

sentence: A first impression is that our technique is more general and will probably give looser bounds, but may be applicable to a wider range of problems not only ones that have specifically that type of covariance, just like DEMINE vs Pearson's correlation.

sentence: But at the same time we also have questions on how much additional insight it brings, as it's not an apples to apples comparison, so neither tight or loose estimations diminish the value of both types of approaches.

sentence: "What can be said about how computationally demanding the procedure is? running label propagation within meta learning might be too costly. "
label: nonarg

sentence: >>> In few-shot learning, episodic paradigm proposed by Matching Networks [1] is widely adopted by current researchers (we follow the same setting to make a fair comparison).
label: concur

sentence: In each episode, a small subset of N-way K-shot Q-query examples is sampled from the training set.
label: concur

sentence: Typically, for 1-shot experiments, N=5, K=1, Q=15 and for 5-shot experiments, N=5, K=5, Q=15
label: concur

sentence: Thus, the number of training examples are Nx(K+Q) (80 for 1-shot and 100 for 5-shot)
label: concur

sentence: Constructing label propagation matrix W involves both support and query examples (80 or 100).
label: concur

sentence: So the dimension of W is either 80x80 or 100x100.
label: concur

sentence: Running label propagation on such small matrix is quite efficient.
label: concur

sentence: "It is not clear how the  per-example scalar sigma-i is learned. (for Eq 2)"
label: nonarg

sentence: >>> In Figure 4 of appendix A, we describe the detailed structure of the graph construction module.
label: dispute

sentence: After we get the per-example feature representation f_{\varphi}(x_i) for x_i, we feed it into the graph construction module g_{\phi}. The output of this module is a one-dimensional scalar.
label: concur

sentence: f and g are learned in an end-to-end way in our approach.
label: concur

sentence: "solving Eq 3 by matrix inversion does not scale. Would be best to also show results using iterative optimization "
label: nonarg

sentence: >>> We want to answer this question from two aspects.
label: concur

sentence: On one hand, few-shot learning assumes that training examples in each class are quite small (only 1 or 5).
label: concur

sentence: In this situation, Eq (3) and the closed-form version can be efficiently solved, since the dimension of S is only 80x80 or 100x100.
label: concur

sentence: On the other hand, there is plenty of prior work on the scalability and efficiency of label propagation, such as [2], [3], [4], which can extend our work to large-scale data.
label: concur

sentence: On miniImagenet, we performed iterative optimization and got 53.05/68.75 for 1-shot/5-shot experiments with only 10 steps.
label: concur

sentence: This is slightly worse than closed-form version (53.75/69.43), because of the inaccurate computation and unstable gradients caused by multiple step iterations.
label: concur

label: nonarg

label: nonarg

sentence: A1: First, the size of search space is not determined by the number of operations but the number of connections.
label: dispute

sentence: The search space of our method is different from exiting NAS methods in that the number of input of certain operation is not limited.
label: dispute

sentence: Second, the search space without block share is even much larger than existing NAS methods.
label: dispute

sentence: Third, we can trivially extend our DSO-NAS to accommodate more operations such as dilated conv like our ongoing experiments on PASCAL VOC semantic segmentation task, we extend our search space to accommodate 3x3 and 5x5 separable convolution with dilated = 2.

sentence: 1. We fully understand your concern and we have added detailed description in the supplemental materials to show the hyperparameters we use for baseline methods in the revision.
label: concur

sentence: 2. We would like to argue that constrained optimization based formulation itself is not designed to achieve better distortion compared with regularized optimization based formulation.
label: concur

sentence: So there is no surprise that our algorithm’s distortion is not the best.
label: concur

sentence: On the other hand, as mentioned by the other reviewer, distortion is usually not that essential in adversarial attacks as long as it is maintained in a reasonable range.
label: concur

sentence: We could actually remove the distortion column, instead, we chose to include it just to show that we did not trade a lot of distortions (to make problem much easier) and thus gains speedup.
label: concur

sentence: From our experimental results, you can see that our proposed method achieves significant speedup while keeping the distortion around the same level as the best baselines.
label: concur

sentence: 3. Thank you for your suggestion.
label: nonarg

sentence: We have further added success rate vs queries plot (for black-box case) and loss vs iterations plot (for white-box case) in the revision.

sentence: As you can see, in terms of number of iterations / queries, our method still outperforms the other baselines by a large margin.
label: concur

sentence: 4. Thank you for your suggestion.
label: nonarg

sentence: We have further added experiments on ResNet V2 model and averaging over 500 correctly classified pictures to strengthen our result.
label: concur

sentence: Again, this additional experiments show that our method outperforms the other baselines for both white-box attack and black-box attack.
label: concur

sentence: 5. Regarding poor time complexity in practice, first, as you mentioned, adversarial training currently is quite slow due to the slow adversarial attack steps.
label: concur

sentence: Better time complexity of adversarial attack could significantly speed up adversarial training algorithms.
label: concur

sentence: Second, it is worth noting that the running time complexity of adversarial attack also highly depends on the input size.
label: concur

sentence: For example, if you attack a CIFAR-10 classifier or an MNIST classifier, it could take only seconds per attack even for the slowest algorithm since the input size is only 32 by 32 (or 28 by 28).
label: concur

sentence: However, if you attack a ImageNet classifier or even higher dimensional data classifier, it could take significantly longer time (minutes).
label: concur

sentence: That is why reducing the runtime of adversarial attack is very important.
label: concur

sentence: We changed Section 3.1 to explain that the posterior dependence on pairs of adjacent frames is to have temporally local latent variables that capture the ambiguity for only that transition, a sensible choice when using i.i.d. Gaussian priors.
label: concur

sentence: Another choice is to use temporally correlated latent variables, which would require a stronger prior (e.g. as in Denton & Fergus (2018)).
label: concur

sentence: For simplicity, we opted for the former.
label: concur

sentence: The blurriness in a VAE can indeed be attributable to a weak inference model.
label: concur

sentence: Note that our VAE variant and both SVG variants are able to predict sharp robot arms in the BAIR dataset, but often blur out the small objects being pushed.
label: concur

sentence: We tried recurrent posteriors and learned priors with our models, and the results were similar.
label: concur

sentence: We are now running additional experiments with a deeper encoder and with more filters.
label: concur

sentence: Although in principle a strong inference model could produce sharper images, an alternative approach is to use better losses, which is the approach we chose in this work.
label: concur

sentence: It is an interesting suggestion to experiment with the effect of the hyperparameters on the trade-off between realism and diversity.
label: concur

sentence: We are currently running experiments for various weightings of the KL loss and the adversarial loss, and we plan to include results that illustrate the trade-offs based on these hyperparameters.
label: concur

sentence: We also plan to include results on the trade-offs between accuracy and realism.
label: concur

sentence: In fact, a recent result [1] proves that this is a fundamental trade-off for all problems with inherent ambiguity.
label: concur

sentence: The statement that “GANs prioritize matching joint distributions of pixels over per-pixel reconstruction" is a criticism of per-pixel losses, and not of VAEs in general. We clarified in the introduction that VAEs can indeed model joint distributions of pixels.

sentence: 1. You are right that Frank-Wolfe would be advantageous over PGD when the constraints are more complicated and adversarial attack may not be such a case.
label: concur

sentence: Yet it is also well-known that Frank-Wolfe has quite different optimization behavior compared with PGD even though they have the same order of convergence rate.
label: concur

sentence: Therefore, it is interesting and important to examine the performance of Frank-Wolfe algorithm for adversarial attack, given the fact that PGD has been shown to be a very effective for adversarial attack.
label: concur

sentence: In fact, from our work, we found that Frank-Wolfe based methods are generally more efficient than PGD method.
label: concur

sentence: From another perspective, Frank-Wolfe solves the problem by calling Linear Minimization Oracle (LMO) over the constraint set at each iteration.
label: concur

sentence: This LMO shares the same intuition as FGSM, which also tries to linearize the neural network loss function to find the adversarial examples.
label: concur

sentence: In this sense, it is a quite natural attempt to revisit FGSM under the Frank-Wolfe framework.
label: concur

sentence: 2. We are sorry maybe we didn’t explain it very well in the paper, but this is a misunderstanding.
label: dispute

sentence: We indeed compared our method with generalized I-FGSM/BIM, which is exactly the same as PGD (In [Madry et al.] they also mentioned this in Section 2.1 and they refer it as FGSM^k).
label: concur

sentence: We decide to just call it PGD in the revision to avoid confusion.
label: concur

sentence: Indeed, theoretically we can only prove for $\lambda$ = 1 case.
label: concur

sentence: Yet we found that larger \lambda brings us more speedup.
label: concur

sentence: We have added further empirical evidence (performance comparison of our method with different \lambda in Figure 1 in the revised paper) to justify it.
label: concur

sentence: Intuitively speaking, using lambda>1 is essentially a “relax and tighten” step by first relax the constraint to make the problem easier, and then tighten it back to the real constraint.
label: concur

sentence: The “relax and tighten” idea has been widely used in constrained optimization, and in this paper we adapted this idea into Frank-Wolfe algorithm to make it even faster.
label: concur

sentence: 4. [Lacoste-Julien 2016] considered the general first-order Frank-Wolfe algorithm for nonconvex smooth optimization.

sentence: We would like to thank the reviewer for the time and useful feedback.

sentence: Our response is given below.
label: nonarg

sentence: - Relationship to z-conditioning strategy in BigGAN.
label: nonarg

sentence: Thanks for pointing out the connection to this concurrent submission.
label: nonarg

sentence: We will discuss the connections in the related work section.
label: nonarg

sentence: The main differences are as follows:
label: nonarg

sentence: 1. BigGAN performs conditional generation, whilst we primarily focus on unconditional generation.
label: concur

sentence: BigGAN splits the latent vector z and concatenates it with the label embedding, whereas we transform z using a small MLP per layer, which is arguably more powerful.
label: concur

sentence: In the conditional case, we apply both additive and multiplicative interaction between the label and z, instead of concatenation as in BigGAN.
label: concur

sentence: 2. Overall BigGAN focusses on scalability to demonstrate that one can train an impressive model for conditional generation.
label: concur

sentence: Instead, we focus on a single idea, and show that it can be applied very broadly.
label: concur

sentence: We provide a thorough empirical evaluation across critical design decisions in GANs and demonstrate that it is a robust and practically useful contribution.
label: concur

sentence: - Propagation of signal and ResNets.
label: nonarg

sentence: Indeed, ResNets provide a skip connection which helps signal propagation.
label: concur

sentence: Arguably, self-modulation has a similar effect.
label: concur

sentence: However, there are critical differences in these mechanisms which may explain the benefits of self-modulation in a resnet architecture:
label: concur

sentence: 1. Self-modulation applies a channel-wise additive and multiplicative operation to each layer.
label: concur

sentence: In contrast, residual connections perform only an element-wise addition in the same spatial locality.
label: concur

sentence: As a result, channel-wise modulation allows trainable re-weighting of all feature maps, which is not the case for classic residual connections.
label: concur

sentence: 2. The ResNet skip-connection is either an identity function or a learnable 1x1 convolution, both of which are linear.
label: concur

sentence: In self-modulation, the connection from z to each layer is a learnable non-linear function (MLP).
label: concur

sentence: - Reading Figure 2b, one could be tempted to draw a correlation between the complexity of the dataset and the gains achieved by self-modulation over the baseline (e.g., Bedroom shows less difference between the two approaches than ImageNet). Do the authors agree with that?
label: nonarg

sentence: Yes, we notice more improvements on the harder, more diverse datasets.
label: concur

sentence: These datasets also have more headroom for improvement.
label: concur

sentence: 1. I feel the approach to implicitly assume that the classifiers to be compared are already "reasonably accurate"; since if not, both classifiers might be easily falsified by certain trivial examples, making the "disagreed examples" not as meaningful. If that is true, I would suggest the authors to make this hidden assumption clearer in the paper
label: nonarg

sentence: Response: Thanks for pointing it out.
